reviewText: If you’re a fan of frustratingly difficult platformers, crude humor, old NES games, or the AVGN on YouTube, then you should check this game out. It pretty much plays like a NES game, though the graphics and music are *slightly* more modern. It’s hard, but not too hard. It gets easier if you keep practicing, and is very rewarding when you manage to finish a level. There’s also tons of references to NES games, which you’ll probably know from AVGN’s videos, and the music is awesome too.\n\nMy only complaint is that it seems to crash quite a lot, especially when I’m near the end of a level. Ugh. Maybe that's just me.

reviewText:
Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is a 2D, 8 bit retro style 'torture' platformer. After a brief tutorial level to kickoff the game, it opens up to eight selectable levels. A few are far easier than others. There is a lot of parody going on here. Levels reminiscent of old Nintendo games like Castlevania, Metroid, Super Mario Bros 2 and Zelda 2. You'll even find an 8 bit parody of dirty Atari games. Once you complete those eight, then the final LJN style level gets revealed. It is all based on the comedy from the Angry Video Game Nerd web series that has been around for a decade. Its a good game that doesn't offer any unique features that aren't found in other Nintendo games. If you're looking for something fresh and original gameplay wise, you won't find it here.

The game plays a lot like Mega Man. Jump, shoot (with no autofire), duck and use a special item. The only difference is there is 8 way shooting like Contra. You can even hold the trigger to plant your feet so you don't walk as you aim diagonal. The items are few and far between. The tutorial level will walk you through all them. Glitch gremlin that I think kills everything killable on screen? Seven hours into the game and I still don't know for sure. Super Mecha Death Christ definitely kills everything on screen. Things like a rock that do little to no damage. Its just in the game so the Nerd can make a joke. The Nerd can even pick up a superscope weapon that does more damage, but one hit and you've lost it. A lot of times you'll find it in areas with unkillable enemies.

Even as a torture platformer, the game isn't that difficult. Timing is key. More than missing a jump, its missing a jump at the wrong time might get you hit and you'll fall in a pit. Each level is around 10 minutes. You have health measured in beer. Pick up a beer to restore your health. On easy you can walk into enemies with no regard for your life. Normal difficulty and up you have to have skills to not die from health loss. Each enemy causes you to get knocked back which becomes deadly if a pit is around. With that being said, the majority of deaths come from death blocks. Mega Man 2 had spikes, AVGN has deathblocks. These are everywhere! Some are in the ground. Somme are moving. Some are on and off with a timer. Some appear only when you get close to them. If you're not paying attention, to where you step, you're dead!

Nin-Toasters get used as checkpoints. These are pretty frequent. When you die, you respawn, but not after seeing a death screen with a randomly generated death phrase that usually involves an animal, a fluid and an body hole. You cannot turn off these death screens. It could be to hide a loading screen. You need to see it for a few seconds before pushing jump to get back to the action. Most torture platformers just drop you right back into the action.

Each level is pretty straight forward, but still allows for exploration here and there. You'll even find three extra characters to play as. Each has their own style and can be toggled on the fly with the shoulder bumpers. Mike has a high Luigi jump and can use a short range light sabre to break through walls that get highlighted as you draw near. He also makes invisible platforms appear. Couch Guy has a wave attack from his guitar that will go through blocks when the Nerd's gun can't. His jump is short, so he's better for SHMUP sections of the game. Finally '♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥' has a double jump and a short range arced attack, but can't jump as high as the Nerd. He's good for accessing different areas. For the most part, these extra characters are only used for finding secret areas, that have cameos from other ScrewAttack friends along with plenty of beer and 1-ups.

The enemies feel diverse, but there isn't a huge variety. Each level swaps out enemy sprites. High bouncing enemies, enemies that attract to you, wave pattern enemies, floor spikes that shoot up, hovering enemies, circular flying unkillable fireballs and so on. Each level has its own unique big enemies. Snowmen that belch giant snowballs. Giant turd balls that spit dookie at you in Hell. Axe throwers in the Castlevania level. Each enemy's death had particle effects that felt satisfying. At the end of each level is of course a boss, straight from AVGN's history of evil. Jason Vorhees, Satan, Dr. Jekyll / Mister Hyde, General Custer and so on. Most of the bosses just fly in a figure eight pattern.

Unlike most torture platformers, there was dynamic gameplay. Going from a platformer to a sidescrolling SHMUP. Riding down a hill one a dead corpse, streaking blood behind you. Hopping on a giant laser shark and tearing through lava. These were all a lot of fun to break up the levels. Even with each level having its own theme, there were things gimmick wise to make them stand out. The Castlevania level has a series of timed on and off death blocks. The dirty Atari level has bouncing platforms under your feet. The snow level had ice to slide on. The Zelda 2 level had keys to unlock doors. The haunted level has moving block platforms like Super Mario World and darkness outside of a short illumination around the Nerd. The Mega Man future level had timed laser beams and timed on / off platforms. It was able to keep the challenges dynamic.

It is no doubt a good game for fans that like Mega Man's gameplay. There are just little things that get in the way. The text box at the bottom of the screen with the Nerd talking is a distraction and obscures the action. In fact, the entire game is just a distraction. There are laser lights panning through some levels. Things flying everywhere. Even a vomit inducing waterfall ala Super Mario Bros 2. Half a dozen fireballs flying in a circle, bouncing on platforms, while enemies float toward you! Its all very busy, but that's probably to keep your eyes off the death blocks! The comedy also misses its mark, but I feel a lot of comedy games aren't that funny. Maybe its lacking the Nerd's delivery. Its just not as funny in text form when I'm too busy playing the game to read it.

Playing normal mode first took 2 hours for the first 8 levels and 4 hours for the final level. I sank around 100 lives just for the final boss. Then I discovered how to plant my feet by holding the trigger to shoot diagonal without walking. Normal difficulty gives you unlimited continues and 30 lives. I felt the intensity when I had died 10 times on a boss and I was coming to my final life to beat him. Easy difficulty gives you more health and unlimited lives ensuring you'll get through the game. There are higher difficulties, but normal was enough for me. I have a feeling you can complete easy difficulty in under 2 hours.

To summarize, its the best AVGN game you could hope for. Easy difficulty makes it so everyone can complete the game. If it wasn't for easy difficulty I wouldn't recommend it. I'd recommend it more for fans of old Nintendo games than AVGN fans. If you're into 8-bit Nintendo games, especially Mega Man. Get it. Also take note that 50% of players have the 100 deaths achievement. So does that mean on easy mode they beat it in under 100 lives or did they just give up and not complete it?

reviewText:
One of the most frustrating, yet fun to play platformers I've ever had the pleasure of playing. A game based on the hit, internet sensation the Angry Video Game Nerd, a character portrayed by James Rolfe whom reviews older games ranging from the Atari, to the SEGA Genesis to the NES and a bunch more.

Off the bat, the game starts out by introducing the Angry Video Game Nerd (or AVGN for short) before he is sucked into the TV (by the balls no less!) and is forced to play through what he calls hell. The stages, quotes, etc are references to older video games and episodes he has done in the past. The game itself conveys a traditional 8-Bit art style for the majority of assets used in the game aswell as play the expected 8-bit style music to go along with them.

Now, personally, I love this game and actively recommend it to everyone that loves/loved watching AVGN and likes tough platformers in general. The game plays out very similarly to classic MegaMan games and Mario Bros, since the Nerd has his standard jump, shoot and crouch, as well as a few nifty temporary power-ups you can pick up across the stages - these range from the Glitch Gremlin (a green creature that glitches the game and often helps with progression as it halts both stage hazards and enemies), the Super Mega Death Christ (Yes lol, a power up that destroys every enemy present on the screen at the time.), an upgraded gun for the Nerd (Has a much bigger hitbox than his standard light gun) and rocks (Yes rocks, like those found on one of his older episodes that he says is useless because of the low travel distance and low damage).

The game has a 3 damage health system and lives (unless you pick a higher or lower difficulty setting in which the game alters these). 3 beer bottles pretty much signal how many more hits you can take before dying, and the lives, like in older Megaman games, means how many times you can retry before being kicked out from the stages. There are also toasters (checkpoints) scattered across the stage to mark your progress on any given stage, but they are optional to activate as there are also beer bottles scattered across to help restore health to you - and there's also secret characters you can unlock all based on his show.

Stage Progression~ Generally, excluding the tutorial stage - you pick a stage in a similar fashion to MegaMan games, there are 8 in total. Each stage has their own deathtraps, some will take a point of damage, and some, like the golden skull blocks found across every stage, will kill you in one hit. Some zones are based around very careful and timing based jumps, movement, etc - like some zones will have an enemy type that is there to hinder you while you do a section, it's all very much reminiscent of the old formula of games back in the day - and like those games, this game isn't very forgiving.

In general, if you're a fan of the AVGN no doubt you'll already have this, but if you're a fan of tough NES-like platformers, get this game. From the obscenely ridiculous references to the appealing art style, this game screams AVGN charm.

B+

reviewText:
I want to hate this game, but the more I am playing it, the more I am loving it. :)

It's after the Unfair Mario the most irritating, challenging, annoyingly hard, frustrating game I've ever played. :)

But I will lie if I would say it's not funny.

This game made me laugh hard a lot of times. It made me feel exactly like a proper Angry Video Game Nerd. And that's the beauty of this game!

I will play this game again (and again and again...) not only to get all the achievements, but also to experience that feeling of satisfaction after completing it (on very hard will be interesting).

Total must play for all the AVGN fans. And for those who don't know AVGN? It might be too frustrating, but still worth a go. ;)

Thrust me, no platform game will be too hard after playing Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures. :D

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the Angry Video Game Nerd webseries, you'll like this game a lot. It does a great job of emulating the Nerd's typical brand of crude, geeky humour. The game is all about what the show is about: raging at old-school, hardcore gameplay that is often frustratingly hard.

It plays just like a classic Nintendo platformer, with levels poking fun at famous - as well as infamous - games of the 80's and 90's. What is great is that it throws these old-school frustrations at you without it being badly designed. It's done in such a way that it is hard not because it's poorly designed, like many of the Nerd's most despised games, but because it requires skill and some effort. It's not unfair if you start at the easiest settings.

The Nerd humour is recognizable in every element of the game: there's a randomly generated line of cursewords if you die, Mecha Jesus powerups, a laser-shooting shark in Hell, snowboarding on Santa's corpse, sh*t pickles and gratitious amounts of potty humour. Each level is distinct and full of geeky references to the show.

In the style of Capcom classics like Mega Man or DuckTales, you can start at any level you want, with an additional final level opening up once you beat all of them. Each one is based on different Nerd episodes and video games. At one point you are fighting Doom-inspired poop demons and a big-toothed Satan in Hell, the next moment you play through a colourful level reminiscent of Super Mario World and in another instance you find yourself shooting ghosts and zombies in a Castlevania-based world. There's even a level based on the 'Atari Porn Games' episode which really must be seen to be believed.

Hidden inside the game are three additional playable characters from the Cinemassacre.com universe as well as cameos of Screwattack.com stars. Fans of the Nerd will know what I am talking about. Power-ups include Super Mecha Death Christ and the Glitch Gremlin, two funny allies that attack all enemies on screen. There's also somewhat useless grenades, poking fun at that one useless power-up that every video game in the 80s and 90s seemed to have.

It's that parody element that makes this game so great. It's not just an old-school 'NES-hard' game, it's also a parody of every game ever made in that genre, both the classics and the ones that are the subjects of the Nerd's crudely graphic tirades. If you like that type of humour and are a fan of the show, this game is for you. If you are unfamiliar with the AVGN and the show's inside jokes, the game falls a bit short, however. Look past the Nerd twist given to classic gaming tropes and the levels turn out to be fairly similar in gameplay elements and are only different enough in the visual department.

If you like old-school, NES-hard platformers, you will feel right at home. You will die. A lot! At the easiest setting, you have unlimited lives, plenty of checkpoints and more health. The credits will roll in a few hours. Try normal, hard or one of the unlockable even harder (!) modes and you will face a much more meaty challenge that will leave even the most veteran gamer screaming in frustration.

There are plenty of similar old-school platform games available on Steam. Wether or not you want to buy this particular one ultimately boils down to the question of wether or not you are a fan of the Nerd. If you are, it's worth your ten bucks. If you aren't, it's just one of many games to choose from for fans of this genre. You won't get much of the inside jokes that make up much of what sets this game apart from others. Thankfully, the overlap between genre fans and the AVGN fandom is probably big enough to make this a game I can recommend.

reviewText:
After finishing the game on EASY, i think is time to do a little review to you all.

Yep, i did all this in 80 Minutes, and i'm proud of it.

Anyways, i have to say that AVGNA is not perfect, it has his flaws that makes the game unfair and sometimes not beatable at the first try.
I'm going to split this in two fases

Number One: The Good Things
Number Two: The Bad Things

Let's start.

The Good Things
1. The game itself as a potential concept that brings me to say that the platformer element is there at any moment,
Sometimes unfair, sometimes really funny and addicting.

2. Good, ♥♥♥♥ing, 8-Bit SOUNDTRACK.

3. The ambientation is awesome, colorful and good looking.

4. You can finish the game in one sit, so no problem if you are an hardcore player.

5. Is worth all your money.

The BAD Things
1. Blocks and traps. I'm sure that everyone is going to say that a platformer needs to have blocks and traps everywhere, but lemme say, that having a block is a thing, having a block that you can see only if you are near to it, is a ♥♥♥♥ING SUICIDE.

2. Well, It's, short. Too much short for a game that values 10 euros, no offense.

3. This is not too much of a bad thing, but prepare to ♥♥♥♥ing swear your balls off, because this game is HARD even on easy.

Final vote? Well, i don't like to give a rating to the games i play but whatever, let me do it.
I'm giving

8.5/10 to this game.

Avoiding all the flaws, i'm sorry to give such a low raiting, the game itself is a LOT enjoyable, and you are going to have so much fun, but when you are near to the end, you can see that they run out of time and ideas. They made an entire map full of blocks that appears only if you are near of it, and that's unfair, pretty damn unfair.

The game itself is GOOD really GOOD!
So buy bud, grab some goodies and have fun.

Thanks for reading, Laguna's off.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by the nerd's furious ranting (which you'll be exposed to every time you die).

You start with eight levels, each one will kill you about 10-20 times on average.

Then you unlock the final level and that one will kill you 100+ times.

You can hold the right trigger to stand in place and fire in a direction (could have used knowing that before I got to the final boss thx).

If you've got three or four hours and a penchant for classic AVGN humor then I give this a recommendation. The game is sprinkled with his hilarious red-hot fury, plus a respectable difficulty.

reviewText: Angry Video Game Nerd has had one hell of a ride. A popular youtube show that paid the wave of youtube comedy we know today. A movie thats out today and a video game thats right here on steam. But will this be the game you will want to play ? We play as the angry game nerd who gets trapped in Game Land. So he has to conquer all the levels to get out. So how is this game ? Personally i really enjoyed it. This game is a shooter platformer in the style of contra. The game also is quite difficult and one of the hardest games i have played. The game has a few problems. The level desing is pretty bad. The controls are kinda stiff at moments cause the game requires a split second reaction time. The game is also quite buggy.The game has this really annoying thing called Death Blocks which seems like all levels are made. If you touch em thats it game over and its quite annoying that youre jumps need to be very persise to not get killed by em. Overall Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is a really fun platforming game with an exceptional soundtrack and its also really fun to play. Its also quite short and i suggest you get this game on sale. I give Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures a 7/10\n\nFor more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Before people get angry, yes I like AVGN, I like challenging platformers, I like chiptune music and 8-bit grapichs, etc. and I really really wanted to like this game.

However, I am also of the opinion that if you are parodying something by doing the same thing ironically and then charging money for it, you are still doing the same thing as the thing you parody, and there lies the real problem: strip away the funny presentation and this is the very type of game that James Rolfe makes fun of in his videos, a game filled with fake difficulty to artificially pad out the play time.

Yes, I get it, it's meta jokes, and the jokes are fun... the first time, then comes the major grind to actually beat the levels with insane unfair difficulty. The levels are fairly well designed in of themselves and are amusingly parodying many of the games reviewed on the show, but the platforming controls are rather stiff, hitboxes are often bigger/smaller than they look and obviously the game does everything to kill you as much as possible, though not in a funny invisible block near a pit" kind of way which would give it a bit of a puzzle element
date: here it's just by throwing a lot of ♥♥♥♥ at you at once and having you deal with it through sheer pressure.\n\nAlso while other fake difficulty parody games like I Wanna Be That Guy at least have the decensy to not throw you back to the beginning unless you pick the higher difficulties when you die
recommended: here it does just that on everything but Easy when running out of extra lives which I find to be a major flaw from a modern perspective
hoursPlayed: no matter how retro or thematically appropriate it is. And before you say "just go play on Easy then"
voteText: I would if it didn't give me more HP than normal
helpfulPercent: make bosses stupidly easy to beat and lock off several achivements
votesHelpful: which obviously isn't very enjoyable
votesTotal: and it still doesn't fix the hitbox and stiff controller issue.\n\nIgnoring the difficulty
votesFunny: the game is also rather short. If you get good at this I could imagine you would be able to beat the entire thing in 2-3 hours
commentsCount: though it does have a fair ammount of hidden secrets and replay value for the really really hardcore crowd when you unlock the truly ridicolous difficulty levels
column16: so it's not that big of a problem
column17: but still worth noting.\n\nBasically
column18: if you don't mind NES games that beat your ♥♥♥ with fake difficulty to the max and aren't affraid to start from the beginning of a stage (or the game itself) every time you die
column19: you will probably love this game. Fans of AVGN may also appreciate the referencial humor to both the show itself and the games that he have played. However
column20: the game still isn't up to modern standards in many respects
column21: and it is rather hypocritical

reviewText: When you design a game to include bad mechanics on purpose as a parody of games with bad mechanics, there comes a point where you cross a line and have made a bad game yourself. Unfortunately, AVGN Adventures falls into this category. The level design is lazy and uninspired. The enemies and bosses are boring and game relies much too heavily on instant kill blocks everywhere for difficulty in place of clever level design. I haven't seen that many AVGN videos, so I'm sure I missed out on some inside jokes, but if there are half as many poop jokes there as in this game, I'm pretty sure I'm not missing out. Overall, the game isn't terrible. The controls are pretty tight and there's some decent music, but I can't recommend buying this at full price.

reviewText: Remember that gut feeling difficult games give you when you're fighting tooth and nail to pass a certain level? AVGN Aventures is full of that. Well designed levels put your patience to the test but more importantly- your skills. If you can bear some vulgar, crude humor, give it a go.

reviewText:
First off, I wanna say that even on Easy, the game is very hard, and it reaches ridiculous levels of hard in some places; Especially the final boss in my opinion, though that's probably because I don't play hard platformers all that much.

Other than that, this game gives a pretty damn good challenge, but at the same time, it really does make you wanna rage; It's basically showing you what's it like to be in a frustrating game that AVGN played, so if you're inexperienced with platformers, I'd think about it real hard before getting it, or try playing some free ones or emulated ones.

Though I do feel that the difficulty is fake at some parts. You probably can't even get through some parts without dying, and if you're just here for a fun-filled game, that kind of can hinder the enjoyability, at least in my opinion. Hoping the second one is a bit more easier.

Other than that, it's a good game.

reviewText: A very, very good game. 7.5/10. Looking forward to the sequel. I feel like the game should've had more blasting up, more upgrades, a sliding move, less death traps and less death blocks. What I mean is the game is mostly about the death traps, I think it should've been more about blasting up enemies or possibily using a close combat weapon (maybe there is but I didn't get there.) I like to see this game kinda similar to Mega Man or Alien Hominid. Actually, Alien Hominid is similar to Mega Man except the controls are better and you even get to charge up your attack. But high five to the creator and his sense of humor. When you die, there's a complaint generator but most of them are too weird or sexual and doesn't sound like something AVGN would really say, or at least the younger AVGN wouldn't say. Who doesn't appreciate good effort, creativity and a retrostyle game? It's pretty difficult, but good luck and have fun.

reviewText: AVGN Adventures is a 2D action platform game that plays similarly to Mega Man. So even though I'm recommending this, it's really only for AVGN fans. Everyone else might just think of this as a needlessly difficult game.

reviewText: Lazy, frustrating design and very unfunny - AVGN Adventures unfortunately does not contain much of any of the sarcastic wit of the actual show/AVGN brand and instead focuses solely on the vulgar and crude elements. There's potential here with decent controls and above average spritework but it is quickly squandered in gameplay aside from the outstanding soundtrack and occasional fun reprieve. There's a heavy reliance on 1-hit kill tiles and trollish blind traps to create a crutch of artificial difficulty that takes the place of interesting and iterative level design. Enemies, jokes and references get recycled over and over through the game to the point of tedium. As a fan of AVGN and very difficult platformers I was very disappointed but played through to the end to see if it got any better, it did not.

reviewText:
Angry Video Gamer Nerd Adventures This game is based on the internet (and one of my favorite) Internet sensations. The Angry Video Game Nerd. For people who's don't know him he basically reviews ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games from the NES, SNES, N64, or any game that is from the 80's/90's/or early 2000's games.

The Story
Now Usually I go into depth in to the game's story but unfortunately I can't as unless you know who AVGN is from the start of playing this game then unfortunately you want get any sort of story or context of this game.
But really even going into depth about some sort of story there really isn't much of a story but more of references to some sort of character from the Angry Video Game Nerd Universe in each level as a boss. Not only this but the level design is purposely designed to be what AVGN has been complaining about in most games. For example

- things that kill you in one hit or mistake
- Ice Stages
- Weird/ Hard stage Design
- And so much more.

So I Highley Recommend you watch the AVGN on Youtube before playing.
https://www.youtube.com/user/JamesNintendoNerd

Gameplay
As you can tell from the game's trailer, the game is a horizontal 2-D side scroler which is a great feel for his type of game. The controls feel great with a controller, with a keyboard it feel weird more than anything.
The Level design is hard but this is genius as this can make us fell like how AVGN would feel for every horrible game he has ever played. It's that good that every time you die that you get a quote from AVGN that would also show how you would feel. Or at the very least make you laugh. And when you die. The death screen joke from the Friday the 13th NES Review is in this.

OverallThe game is really intended for the common AVGN fan, and is once again highly recommended you watch the AVGN Series before playing. It's one cool, Hard, Unfair yet funny experience.

reviewText: This game is a real challenge for gamers and fans of the AVGN. The story is pretty simple, the Nerd and his friends get sucked into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game and have to survive in order to get home. Fans of the nerd will enjoy seeing all of the different references from his many episodes from the Game Graphic Glitch Gremlin to the Beat It and Eat It level based off of the Nerds Atari Porn episode. But once you get to Laughin Jokein numbnuts, you really got to buckle down for a real insanity. The other playable characters have their advantages and disadvantages, Mike is good in finding hidden locations and one ups next to the special cameos, Guitar Guy is good for some of the bosses and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t man is good when you want to play a game with a heavier gameplay. It pisses me off and even I got around to dropping the F Bomb after dyeing so many times. First time gamers won't be able to beat the game without seeing the Game Over Screen several times, but it's also a great challenge for hard core gamers that want to unlock the more challenging modes in the game. So in other words, it's good that it's bad. It's the kind of game that pisses you off that it makes you want to beat it, show him who's the boss!

reviewText:
Though this game is somewhat of a novelty it plays true to the world that James Rolfe has created. Being a long time AVGN fan I can say that, if you are the same as me and have been following the nerd then you will appreciate supporting him by purchasing the game and having some fun with it.

My biggest complaint is the this game is DAMN hard, and as it should be, being remeinscient of NES hard titles, it likes to take all of the biggest annoying things of the old school video game design and bring them about for a laugh or two.

You can beat the levels I beat 2 of them, but I struggled, and I don't know if it was worth, it's aggravating, and it's awesome everything that I think they were trying to capture with this game design.

reviewText: This is one of the best fan games I have ever seen! The gameplay and the music is so ♥♥♥♥ing awesome and memorable, it's tight as ♥♥♥♥, and it is appropriately challenging. It captures the style of AVGN perfectly and the stages are insane and hilarious. Lots of fun and craziness to be had here, even if you aren't very familiar with AVGN (if you're not into juvenile or corny humor, then just ♥♥♥♥ right off wit ya). If this game came out in the 80s, we would still be singing its praises today. But that doesn't matter; it came out in 2013 and I'm still singing its praises compared to the current video game standards. It's a legitimately awesome game, and an incredible tribute to the Nerd and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ttedly hard NES games of the past.

reviewText:
After finally completing The Angry Video Game Adventures for the first time i can only say...WOW.

STORY: The plot of AVGN Adventures goes like this: One day the Nerd and his friends were playing a ***** game, when suddenly the TV sucks them in, the nerd tries to escape, but he gets grabbed by the sack and he enters Game Land to complete 9 levels and find out who the **** is responsible for this.

PRESENTATION: AVGN Adventures, like many other games, looks like an old retro-NES-SNES-game and by that i mean that the game has a mixture between 8 and 16 bits type graphics and sound (all tho you could argue with 32 bits for the sound, but that's besides the point). The sprites and backgrounds are well done and detailed, the framerate is consistent (at around 60fps) and the music ¡is kick-***!, everything in this game looks colorful, eye catching and different from one and other.

GAMEPLAY: AVGN Adventures plays like a 2D platforming shooter from the NES era with a very high difficulty. You platform around and shoot the enemies with the NES Zapper to progress and you can get upgrades or sub-weapons to add to your arsenal.

The game has 4 Characters to play with and each of them has some especial attribute, tho you do have to find the other characters. First there's The Nerd"

reviewText:
Having been an AVGN fan for a number of years, I was excited to see what the first official video game based on the character would be like. For the three people around who aren't familiar with AVGN, he's a character whose life mission is to play some of the worst video games from the retro era. The original focus was the Nintendo Entertainment System, but games for others systems have also been covered. The brainchild of filmmaker James Rolfe, the nerd is a loud, vulgar, beer-swilling cad who bemoans his need to play these horrible games. The pain is eased in no small measure by his love for Rolling Rock beer.

Angry Video Game Nerd Adventure is very much a fan service game, so it's the dedicated videos of his web-based show that will get the most out of the experience. Borrowing heavily from the 8-bit Mega Man games, the gameplay is classic, tough-as-nails platforming with insane traps, waves of enemeis and frequent deaths. Fans of the aforementioned Mega Man, Metroid, Castlevania and Contra games will appreciate the old school difficulty. While one-hit kills are frequent, you do have a life meter (a line of beer bottles) and you can find health power-ups throughout the level. Searching the levels also unlocks new playable characters. Each level is based on a trope from the AVGN series, with various in-jokes to the series providing much enjoyment to hardcore fans.

While your enjoyment of the crass humor depends on how familiar with the AVGN series you are, the gameplay is accessible for most retro game fans. Your goal is to get from one end of the level to the next and defeat a boss, very simple premise, but the difficulty makes it an endurance test of trial and error. This is by design, since the game is a homage to an era where video games didn't hold your hand and Game Over" meant just that. There is an easier difficulty setting for those who want an easier ride
date: but the true risk and reward comes with the more challenging settings. Since the platforming needs to be precise
recommended: I highly recommend playing with a controller over the mouse and keyboard. The game plays beautifully with my Xbox 360 controller
hoursPlayed: with fast
voteText: responsive and tight controls making the game a blast...even if I'm constantly dying
helpfulPercent: \n\nAVGN Adventures is not a perfect game
votesHelpful: but it's a joy to play if you're a fan of retro side-scrollers and especially fans of the AVGN show. The full price is a little steep for some
votesTotal: but those who make the investment are in for a great time."

reviewText:
For more than a decade, James Rolfe, AKA the Angry Video Game Nerd, has been reviewing some of the worst games ever made.  Now, he is not playing the games, but is in the games.  While playing a bad game is one thing, being inside one is another story.

With the game being based on the Nerd’s show, the game uses material from the various episodes.  This is what will make the game most appealing to fans of the show.  Throughout the game, references to the show make its presence felt.   From stages like Boo! Haunted House coming from his comments to characters like Stuttering Craig as the Ghost of Christmas Past, everything about the game feels like an interactive version of the show.  Even things like the Super Pitfall deathtrap make its way into the game.  To go even further, some people from the show like Guitar Guy are playable characters adding extra variety and strategy.  If you are a fan of the Nerd, part of the fun will come into to finding and determining where all the references are from.

One thing that is surprising about the game is the quality of the music.  Even though this is supposed to be like an 8-bit game, the music is at a level above that.  The way that the music is designed could easily fit into any electronic setting.  For those that found themselves enjoying the music from the BIT.TRIP series, the music will be a perfect fit.

Since this is modeled after 8-bit games, the game also has their challenge.  Excluding the tutorial, every level in the game is hard.  Even with the easy setting’s generous checkpoints and lives, trying to clear a single area can be unforgiving at times.  A prime example of this is in the Haunted House level.  In that stage, the player needs to walk through a long corridor.  While in there, a series of death blocks with make navigating difficult.  That would make it hard enough as is.  However, these blocks are only visible when within a few steps away.  On top of that, make of the floor blocks will collapse when standing on them.  This makes it that either the player has to have fast reflexes or memorized the layout.  With such steep challenge, only those with high skill or tolerance will be able to finish.

Nerd fans will definitely enjoy the game the most, but platforming fans in general will enjoy it.  Its high difficulty is a problem, so casual players might find it too much to handle.  Just remember that he was originally the Angry Nintendo Nerd, and this game personifies the expression “Nintendo Hard.”

reviewText: This game is... interesting. I started out hating this game but quickly started enjoying it. Aside from the sluggish controls, the game is fluid and fun. Paying homage to the great and the horrible games of the NES era, the game has quite a bit of variety but never strays too far from its roots. Being an NES-style game, it's challenging and makes completing a level feel a lot more satisfactory for it, but it's not hard to a point of frustration, at least not on normal difficulty. Being based on James Rolfe's character the Angry Video Game Nerd, the game has a lot of immature humor and unnecessary vulgarity to a point of tedium but if you can look past that, you'll find an enjoyable platformer with a nostalgic feel.

reviewText:
It's nice to see the AVGN himself in a retail game, something I would have never expected, especially for the character I've been watching ever since the first episode of the whole series before it became a series.

The game itself is really, really hard.  Sometimes unfair.  A lot of this requires twitch reflexes and trial and error, but there is always a way through the obstacles.  It's funny how this game is even harder than Freakzone Games' previous game: Manos: The Hands of Fate.  My advice?  Start on easy mode and learn the levels before you tackle normal or higher.

So clearly, the difficulty is what may keep a lot of people away, but there is plenty of appeal to satisfy anyone who can appreciate the difficult yet enjoyable 2D sidescroller fun.  I'd recommend it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is a very challenging game, but it is also a rewarding game. Each level you complete gives you so much satisfaction and energy. The game, for the most part, is never unfair. It is difficult... very difficult, especially on higher difficulties, but its challenges, as well as the 8-bit graphics, awesome music, and the many cameos and references to the AVGN episodes, make it an enjoyable experience. It is a game that pushes you just enough so that you do not want to give up until you beat it.

reviewText:
A very solid game that tries to recreate that old school NES experience, and succeeds. A game that does no handholding, throws you into the middle of a world where you have to time your jumps and platforming, and punishes you for failure.

Although some issues with the game would be mechanics such as the instant-death blocks, which feel like a cheap and lazy way to make the game difficult. Also it is generally believed that the game is a bit too expensive for the amount of content it brings, which is arguable. There may not be a whole lot of levels, but they are all challenging in their own ways and provide a lot for what they are. I have an hour and a half clocked into the game and I've only managed to beat the first level.

With an amazing soundtrack, familiar themes, and very satisfying gameplay, AVGN:Adventures is a great first full-release from ScrewAttack Games. I hope to see more from them in the future.

reviewText: Pretty much what the description says: A Mega Man/Castlevainia style side-scrolling jump 'n' shoot 'em up.\n\nControls are tight and the level design and gameplay (for the most part) offers a pretty fair challenge. reviewText: Remember the days when you use to sit in front of a 20 CRT TV playing side scrollers for hours? You do? Well then
date: this game is for you!\n\nDon't think for a second that this is another rip-off of Super Mario Bros
recommended:
because it's not. Be ready to get your ♥♥♥ kicked while laughing about getting your ♥♥♥ kicked. Your left thumb may even feel that old but familiar feeling of rubbing the d-pad too much. Right Pointer Finger will take his turn shooting/jumping while his best friend Mr. Thumb is having a well-deserved break.  All the stuff you remember and love from retro gaming is here!

I'd hate to see how much time I wasted as a kid playing this kind of game; Steam game tracking will certainly give me a good idea in the near future. The fond memories this game pulls from the back of my mind is what makes this game so special. I have not played a game like this in years!!!

Do yourself a favor... Take a break from the HD games and play this!

Two thumbs up!"

reviewText: Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is a love letter to the 8 bit NES era as well as the era that coined and defined the term NES hard! The game puts you in the role of the easily angered, foul mouthed, ill tempered Nerd as he travels through 8 levels of Game Land" inspired by "Video Game Land" from the late 80s cartoon "Captain N: The Game Master" while the gameplay is inspired by classic retro games like Castlevania
hoursPlayed: Ninja Gaiden and others.\n\nEach level has various nods to games from the past as well as games that The Nerd has reviewed on his web series. For example
voteText: the level "Beat it And Eat It" is inspired by the Atari Porn games for the Atari 2600
helpfulPercent: and the level "Boo! Haunted House" inspired by the "A Nightmare On Elm Street" and "Friday The 13th" NES games!\n\nThe most satisfying thing about this game is the challenge! Yes
votesHelpful: areas of certain levels can be difficult and will even get you to curse like The Nerd himself
votesTotal: but that is what makes this game fun! The process of trial and error while playing through the game and being rewarded for beating the level instead of having you're hand held with a useless guide that shows you how to beat the level or give you recharging health or anything else that current games do nowadays. The game is still very fun as well as rewarding to play and gives you just that right amount of challenge that makes you want to keep on playing til the end!\n\nIf you are a fan of classic "NES hard" games like Castlevania

reviewText:
This is a great game for old-school hardcore gamers who actually like a challenge, unlike what most of today's games give us. *shakes old-man cane*

The graphics are crisp, goofy and well animated.

The sound design is pretty good. I feel as if the game could use more SFX, it seems there isn't as much SFX feedback as one normally gets with this type of game. The music is stellar.

The controls are perfect, though they can change from each level you play, by design.

The only thing that gets a bit old is the over-use of swear words. I understand that it's AVGN thing" but it gets a bit old after a while.

Love the game!  Go buy it.  8/10"

reviewText:
I found this game to be fun... fine is that not good enough for you? You want really things, things that mattered and are relevent to the game in question? Fine, I'll give it to you. This game does have some minor problems, but what game dosen't.
It can feel a little bit floaty and slidy at times, but none of that matters. To some people it may seem generic at first glance, and to a point they are right. But in all honesty, when you are making a game that pays tribute to the NES, you are not going to see to many new things. The game plays well, and the music is kick ♥♥♥. All minor problems you may or may not find with this game don't really matter. Because you will be having fun. When you are having fun, and you hate something, you love hating it. I really don't understand it, but that is how it goes. If you slide a little and you slide into a death block, you will suddenly become ten times as motivated as you were before, just to conquer the stupid level.

Sidenote, play with a controller if at all possible.

reviewText:
There isn't much to the story, but it makes enough sense to get the general idea of the game. I'd say one of the best things in the game is the music. It redefines NES music. Way more chords and bass drums; enough for it to be awesome, but not overused. The amount of humor is incredible for a game that was designed to be very challenging. It gets me stressed, but just enough to influence me to keep going. The references to the bad games James reviewed are everywhere and the bosses are even bigger references. I had a lot of fun playing this and would definitely recommend it to anyone who's up for a challenge.

The story: 4/5 because it relates to the AVGN show's logic and humor perfectly, however it's so simple.

The music: 5/5 because it's just so awesome and I can't get it out of my head.

The gameplay: 4/5 because almost everything is fair and the controls aren't awkward at all.

The characters: 5/5 because each character has their own personality, they relate to the show perfectly and they all serve a purpose somewhere in the game.

Overall rating: 5/5. Excellent game that makes me want to try again and again. Great work!

reviewText:
As a fan of the Nerd (granted much later than most, but I still watched all the episodes) I bought this game when it came out.  The game is hard, and usually still doable with some rage to it.

However, I can't recommend this game to most.

The difficulty is actually the reason I gave up playing this game, as I never even beat it on Normal.  All the bosses fly in a figure 8 pattern and many add projectiles into the mix for added dodging.  I never did beat the final boss, even after 300 lives dedicated to him and his final level (After a while, I could usually reach the boss after burning half my lives on the level - the final boss probably killed about 120 of those lives).

The power ups are rare, so rare that I almost never bothered using them when I found one.  The 'balls' powerup is terrible (as it is supposed to be), the glitch gremlin can freeze things in or out of your way (really depends on timing), and Mecha-Death Christ is usually out of the way (dangerously), and provides a screen nuke for enemies that I can gun down without assistance.  The Super Scope is a nice boost of power, but goes away after just one hit from any hazard... you won't hold onto it for long.

Dont' get me started on the number of insta-death DEATH BLOCKS this game throws at you. You can't even try to count.

It's not the hardest game out there, but only the truly dedicated will beat this game. There are also way harder and more rewarding games to dedicate that time to.  5/10

reviewText:
This is a 2d platform / retro style video game.

I'm a great fan to the AVGN series.
Game is super challenging and frustrating.
A lot of elements are from the old NES era.
One of the games are Mega Man if you look ath the selection screen.

So this is a game that is basic as it can be.
You walk, jump and shoot.
Your mission is to beat every boss from every stages and try to find and save your friends.

Great AVGN 8-bit style.
Cool music and all the elements come back from the series.

In short, a must have game if you love 2d platform.
I give it a score of 8/10.

reviewText:
In their zeal to make a game that features all the things the AVGN has complained about, they managed to make a game that is only slightly below average. One would expect that the novelty would make up for it--having useless power-ups, cheap deaths, and all that were intentional design choices, after all, so you know that you're buying into that when you buy the game. In addition to this, though, AVGN Adventures has clear problems that should have been fixed.

Serious Problems:

Movement. The characters move with all the precision of Meat Boy. This makes playing the level Beat Em and Eat Em"

reviewText: Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is a satire platformer shooter game that requires near perfection and patience.  You start out the game going through an opening level that isn't too hard.  Finishing this intro level unlocks eight different worlds all offering semi unique backgrounds, but all share most of the same elements.  Defeating the eight levels unlocks the tenth level, which does require absolute perfection.  Fans of games that require perfection may like the challenge, but most gamers will probably just be satisfied watching the YouTube videos of James ranting about bad games.\n\nIf you are looking for challenging and unforgiving platformers, this is definitely one of them.  If you want something challenging without being completely unforgiving, I recommend Eversion instead.

reviewText:
I'm working on a video-review of this game, and I have already beated almost the entire game (all I got left is the secret last level), but I think I've played long enough to make a Steam review of the game, and talk about it. As usual, I'm gonna take the bad things the game has out of the way first:

First and foremost, this game can be hard. It depends on your skills on these kind of games. Have you played the old Castlevania games? The 2D Metroids? Megaman? Or even f#cking Super Mario World? If you have not, then you're going to die more than any nooblord in the PC version of Dark Souls, trying to play without the patches, AND USING THE KEYBOARD INSTEAD OF A CONTROLLER. I'M NOT KIDDING. Of course, the game has many difficulty modes, depending of how much of a casual you are, but I got to the last level of the game in almost 4 hours, trying to find everything, and in normal difficulty. Of course I died a lot of times, but you're going to die, it's how this game goes.

The second thing that it might make you regret buying it, is the lenght of the game. It is entertaining and fun to play it, but it's not that long. Dude, It took 4 hours to get to the final level, and I'm pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good at these things, it might take you 6 or so to beat the entire game. You can of course replay the game in other difficulties and all that stuff...But there's not that much reason to replay it, unless you enjoy torturing yourself like the Nerd. And that's the last bad thing the game might have:

If you're not a fan of the Angry Video Game Nerd, or you don't watch his videos, then you're not going to understand shi#t. Pretty much 90% of the game are references to his videos and old-school videogame reviews. ALL THE BOSSES ON THE GAME, ARE THINGS THAT HAVE BEEN SEEN ON HIS VIDEOS (except the Giant-claw, I believe). Before picking up the game, you should check out his Angry Video Game Nerd videos, get some pop-corn, some Rolling Rock beers, have a good time watching him destroy those putrid mother of an #ss games. That said...

This game is BALLS TO THE WALL! It's been long since I found a game with ACTUAL CHALLENGE! I find games like Dark Souls a walk on the park, but this game actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off at random times, because it's as ruthless as games used to be, back on those times. What, you're a casual and a p#ssy? Play it on Easy, you have infinite lifes, double the HP, but in normal, you can take 3 hits before you blow up to pieces, and can only die 30 times before getting a Game over screen. The game over screen doesn't actually make you play from the start of the game, just sends you back to the level select screen, so it's fair, you can beat any level on your first try in 30 levels, if you're competent and don't f#ck up too much. In harder difficulties there's a limit of how much Game Over screens you can take before it actually ENDS the game for you, so yeah, pick your poison motherf#cker.

The graphics, along with the music, are the best thing of the game, everything feels like a mix between NES and SNES graphics, and the soundtrack is just AMAZINGLY AMAZING! I won't lie, the theme for Future F#ckballs 2010" is probably the best one so far

reviewText:
Rated “F” for ♥♥♥♥balls, The Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures lives up to its rating. Developed by FreakZone Games and published by Screw Attack Entertainment this game has been a long time coming and many have looked forward to its release for some time. AVGNA is actually really hard, and almost makes me wonder what the Angry Video Game Nerd himself would say. The game fits into the online series perfectly and any Angry Video Game Nerd fan will love everything that they have incorporated into it.

Covered in nostalgia this game stays true to the 16 bit era, and doesn’t stray from the path at all. I could think of a 100 things that would make this game better, but by adding them in it would drastically change how the game is perceived. When I first started, it almost felt like 1991, coming home from the video store after renting a new Nintendo game. The AVGNA logo sits on a black background with 3 choices, Start, Options and Quit, and reminded me a lot of the old 8 bit style games like Dig Dug or Excite Bike. The language in this game reminds me of Farrah Abraham’s porno, a bunch of awkwardly placed swears revolving around the words ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥♥, whereas in this case its actually funny on purpose. Adding to the awesomeness of the game, not only is your main weapon an old school Nintendo Zapper, but you have enemies like Rob E. Robot and a defecating Rudolph the reindeer.

The story starts off with the Nerd and his friends playing a “♥♥♥♥♥♥” game together, when suddenly his friends are zapped into the TV. The Nerd escapes into the basement but an arm comes out of the TV and grabs him but the balls and pulls him inside. The game begins in Gameland, 3AM. From there the game brings you into a small training level to learn the controls and dynamics. After the tutorial, you are brought to a map screen where you have the choice of 8 worlds. Each are individually themed and named accordingly. To name a few, “♥♥♥♥♥♥♥vania” is reminicient of Castlevania and holds many obstacles similar to the ones you would have encountered playing it, “Beat It & Eat It” has elements of the adult themed Atari game Beat Em & Eat Em. Your ultimate goal throughout the game is to beat the boss at the end of each level and try to get yourself out of GameLand.

At times during gameplay I found myself almost trying to like this game, because upon initial gameplay I was almost taken back by the tremendous difficulty, I feel like this is one of those games where its simplicity makes it almost impossible. Your health is comprised of beer bottles, depending on the difficulty setting you choose you will start with either 3 or 5 beers. Like most platformers the bottles are scattered throughout each level and usually appear after a seemly impossible section to help replenish your life before its so callously taken away. Your main weapon is a Nintendo Zapper and if you can find the upgrade you also have the SNES Super Scope which fires faster and more effectively. Each world has hidden secrets and you can even discover new playable characters with different weapons and abilities. 1UPs are scattered throughout the levels to help replenish the lives lost along the way, as well as a few one time use abilities that have a variety of effects.

I think what it all comes down to with this game is price and how its not reflected in gameplay. I respect the old school retro effect and any of my readers will agree with that, but this game would be amazing and I would love it 10 times more for 4.99. Due to the marketing of the game and the already house hold name of AVGN amongst gamers this game would be understandable at 9.99, but the 14.99 price mark is almost a dig at the fans. What it all boils down to is the game at its base and if its good or not. The graphics are a little more pixelated than I would have expected, and the ratio is a little larger than your normal platformer. The controls are on point and flow well with the game. Overall The Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is certainly worth checking out, and will leave you just as angry as the Nerd himself.

Graphics: 5/10
Playability: 6/10
Story: 6/10
Challenge: 8/10
Replay Value: 6/10

reviewText: When I first heard about this game I was so excited to get it...and frankly it was worth it. Sure it's a pretty hard game, but it's just hard enough that you want to keep playing and show it who's boss. I haven't cursed so much with every loss in a game for quite a while, it actually makes you FEEL like the Nerd himself. Even if you're not a huge fan of AVGN this game is still worth playing, especially if you like old school style games that provide actual challenge. After trying for so long to beat a level it's such a thrill when you finally succeed, and the music is pretty awesome. Go ahead, give it a try.

reviewText:
AVGN Adventures, as you probably figured looking at the screenshots, is a sidescrolling retro style platformer. What makes this one different from all the other retro style platformers is that it is based entirely around the concept and exploits of the Angry Video Game Nerd.

AVGN decides to play a pretty bad game, as he usually does. However, this game decides to pull him through the TV, sucking him into the world of terrible videogames and bad videogame tropes. The plot is very simple, and only really serves the purpose of giving you the setup to actually play through the adventure.

If you're not really a fan of the AVGN series of videos, then this isn't for you; the whole game is designed to be a playable homage to the Nerd and everything that the fans love about him and what he does. The whole game is jam-packed full of references that most people familiar with the series will get and appreciate, as well as a number of deliberately bad game design choices that make their way in as a result of his frequent complaining of said issues in many of his reviews. It all adds up to a game with themes that are very faithful to the titular hero.

The levels are deliberately very tricky, and oftentimes you'll find you die a lot in each one. Most of the levels often have instances of trial and error. You will most likely die not knowing how to navigate certain obstacles the very first time, or not react quickly enough not knowing what's about to come. To offset this style of difficulty, the player is given a total of 30 lives to work with. This is usually enough to make it from beginning to end of a level. But it's in this feature that lies my main criticism with the game.

The system of 30 lives to make it through any given level is fine, however my main issue with this is that upon completing a level, your remaining number of lives will carry over to the level you play next. This means that unavoidably you will always start subsequent levels with significantly fewer lives to work with, and you might find that you won't even have anywhere close enough to beat a level the first time. Get a Game Over, and you lose your checkpoint progress.

There is no way to reset your lives count except by getting a Game Over, either. I've tried to save, quit and come back into the existing save to see if that would work. Sadly the save does save your current lives count, meaning it was intentionally designed that way. So if you begin with a meager 5 lives, you will either want to just kill them off at the start or use them for practice in the early part of the level, because you're probably not going to get too far with them.

That issue aside, AVGN Adventures is a really fun game for fans with great graphics and awesome 8-bit music. Highly recommened if you love AVGN!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is an overall good game. It's not groundbreaking, but it's still an experience.

I think that in order to like this game, you need context of who the AVGN is, and more specifically, what he most often complains about in video games. If you don't have enough context, this game IS MOST LIKELY GOING TO  come over as bad.

Pros:

- The writing is whitty
- The controls are tight
- The music is ♥♥♥♥ing great
- The visuals are incredible.
- The gameplay is fun and challenging
- There are a nice handful of easter eggs
- No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t
- No ♥♥♥♥ing DLC
- Faithful to its source material.
- The powerups are awesome and useful
- It has a lot of AVGN references, but not too many. It doesn't try way to hard to be faithful to its source material.
- The array of characters you can play as who actually have useful abilities.
- Well programmed and almost flawless in performance minus some user triggered glitches.

Cons:
- The level design is suppost to troll you and be like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games the AVGN plays. He always complains about that kinda ♥♥♥♥ in his videos so it makes concept crucial.
- Sometimes it can be very unfair. Some parts of the game can really ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ you off
- Way too much trolling
- Bosses seem to be more luck than skill when beating them
- Some segments you are required to take damage. It's either that or I'm just really ♥♥♥♥ at running along 10 second long floors where spikes occasionally pop out of the floor, and the roof and jumping into the roof spikes, hoping I won't take any damage.

Overall, it's a really fun game. I'd recommend playing with a controlled, because afterall, it is a platformer game. These kind of games are made to be played on controllers.

Overall rating: 7.5 shitpickles out of 10

reviewText:
This is terrible. It is difficult for difficulty's sake and not particularly fun to play.

The powerups range from useless to nonexistent and really it's just a frantic, desperate frustrating race to get to the next safe spot. Everytime you die, the game also gives you a tiresome line about how much it sucks.

Let's be honest here. It's not a great game, even if you ARE a fan of the Nerd. And if you're not a fan, all the less reason to play it. I'ma just get my steam trading card outta this and scram. It's a chore to play, horrible to listen to, and insulting to read. At least when you die, the game itself will agree.

0/10. Only fanboys need apply.

reviewText:
This game is just annoying to play. Whether it was intended or not, the game has pretty generic obstacles and they used every annoying trick in the book just to ♥♥♥♥ you off. I hope you like instant kill blocks every two meters and reskinned fireballs that fly in a vertical or circular pattern.

I am a fan of the show, I've watched pretty much every episode, I watch Monster Madness, James & Mike Mondays etc.

It took me 6 hours and a half with 607 deaths to complete on Normal but I did it. It's Ironic how this game has all the flaws that the AVGN talks about in his show such as not replenishing your health bar before a boss, enemies that come from bad altitudes, you can't hold down the fire button to shoot (So I had to use the turbo/rapid fire button on my controller) and there is no reward for beating a stage. No cutscene, no character unlock (You have to find them through the stages) and I only felt satisfied with beating the final boss because the game was finally over. What a ♥♥♥♥ load of ♥♥♥♥, what were they thinking? If this game was free then it would of been cute but it's not and I didn't really enjoy the game.

If the game was intentionally suppose to be not fun, aggravating as all hell and annoying to play then they got me good.

reviewText: While I do enjoy this game a lot I don't think many people actually would enjoy this platformer. However if you can ignore the language and you like games you can die in a lot over and over again and takes time and memorization to get good at it then this is the game for you.. but I can't see to many people enjoying this. However if you're a huge AVGN fan you'll love this game and all it's entirety! lots of references, dialog from the nerd and more. (and the final boss is annoying but hilarious when you find out who trapped you in this horrible video game world.)

reviewText: Wow, I'm very surprised to see some hate for this game. Let me try to be as objective as possible here. AVGNA is a game that, let's face it, is designed around the problems that James Rolfe has pointed out in his over 100 videos for his popular web series, the Angry Video Game Nerd. AVGNA is mainly a tribute to his legacy of video reviews, but which manages to capture the spirit of that show while also providing humorous dialogue and some pretty fun levels. The control is very good (best played with a controller), the graphics are appealing, the health pickups and one-ups are relatively plentiful, and there are numerous checkpoints scattered generously across the levels. The music is very catchy and gives the game a strong sense of energy. I also enjoyed how you can play as different characters who have different weapons and abilities, if you could find them.\n\nNow let's get to the major complaints. Yes, this game is full of cheap kills. That's part of the point. This game is full of meta jokes because you're playing as the Nerd who has to fight the summation of obstacles that have plagued so many of the terrible games from his youth. As I was playing, I was really thinking Wow
date: this stuff really must've been horrendous" in reference to the games he had to beat for his show. But the beautiful thing about this game is that I feel it never exceeds the threshold. The "cheap" sections really aren't that long
recommended: and the difficult areas are always preceded by easier sections that are meant to teach you the tricks or gimmicks of each level.\n\nFor people who are debating whether or not to buy this game
hoursPlayed: I would say that if you're a fan of AVGN and you like platformers or played them as a kid
voteText: give this one a go. In terms of 2-D platformers that have come out recently
helpfulPercent: this is definitely one of the best. The level design actually had quite a bit of thought put in
votesHelpful: and even though it can be frustrating
votesTotal: if you're smart enough to figure out basic patterns and patient enough to repeat certain sections
votesFunny: you won't regret getting this game. I've been a big fan of James for years and I think that this game stays true to the basic feel of the videos and the attitude he exudes as the Nerd. Plus I loved the humor and self-referential jokes.\n\nTo respond to negative reviews
commentsCount: here's what I have to say: There's no way I can understand complaints about this game being too difficult. Compared to some of the games people of James's generation played growing up

reviewText:
I bought this game after watching a short lets play on Youtube. It seemed like a fun game based on the visuals and concept. Being a fan of the AVGN series I wanted to support that as well.
But boy do I regret spending those buck.

The controls are so stiff that jumping on a platform fails in most cases. It feels like they were intentionally made stiff to subtract from the ability to steer the nerd. The truth I however fear is that the guys who made this  game are inexperienced game devs or simply have no skill in their trade whatsoever OR were so busy thinking of foul words that they didn't have time to test if the game was actually playable.
The good humor from the series is more or less absent in place of just swearing endlessly.
In regard to the indie AVGN fan games I've played (watch episode 115 if unsure of which I'm referring) this doens't present much original content.

The level design is really bad as well. I haven't played for that long because I more or less ragequit due to all these issues I'm adressing here. But I did play all stages. And they're the same: Unfair when they should instead be challenging.
I've played and beaten tons of platform games. Especially old and hard ones. But this simply isn't fun.

I wish there were more positive things to say about this. Unpolished, frustrating, insulting and unworthy of my time.

To sum it up: FreakZone Games did an awful job with this game, and why ScrewAttack would have them make a sequel is beyond my comprehension.

reviewText:
Finished the game in 165 mins or 2hrs 45mins.

...What a disappointment. I'm a Nerd fan. I like how creative he tells how bad a game is. I really wish this game is also creative. It could have been a game about the Nerd and inside a shi*ty game. Instead, it tries to mix shi*ty games and hard games.

There are two kinds of hard games: hard but fair (like VVVVVV, Super Hexagon, Dark Soul), and hard for the sake of hard. This game is the latter.

If you are the kind of player who enjoys games like I Want to be That Guy or Eryi's Action... go play those games. At least those games know that they are hard for hard's sake. AVGN video game pretends that its not these kind of games. It makes for bad gameplay with barely any rewards. Even finishing the game is not satisfying.

If you are a nerd fan, play the game once. If you think you can complete it, then be my guest. If not, look up videos online. You won't be missing much though.

If you are not a nerd fan, I advise you to stay away from this game. I Want to be That Guy or Eryi's Action are better than this game.

reviewText:
Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures (or AVGNA) is an old school nintendo hard platformer based on Cinemassacre James Rolfe's character Angry Video Game Nerd. It features 8 levels and one super tough final level with bosses in the end. The game is designed on the XBOX360-controller, which is definitely the one you should use. AVGNA also has a really intense soundtrack which really makes the levels fun to play.

+Brutally challenging even on the easiest difficulty settings.
+Great soundtrack.
+Tight controls on the XBOX360 pad.
+Nostalgic levels that pay homage to many classics.

-Deathblocks feel a bit cheap and are too abundant.
-Unless you are a fan of AVGN, you won't understand most of the references.

reviewText:
HE'S GONNA TAKE YOU BACK TO THE PAST
TO PLAY A KILLER GAME THAT KICKS ♥♥♥

Well now that that's out of the way, AVGN Adventures is a well-made love letter to all things AVGN. It's filled with all of the things that make the Nerd the Nerd. He complains about various design choices along the way, and when you die you're given a randomly-generated complicatedly vulgar insult about how much he hates the game. Levels, enemies, bosses, and even the pause menu music are based on games he's reviewed. There are plenty of cameos from the Nerd's fellow Internet personalities, and various characters that have been on the show. And the final level and final boss are exactly what and who they should be.

Plus, you know, the level design's pretty darn good, too.

AVGNA is designed to delight through the frustration. It's not I Wanna Be the Guy hard, but it's a tough-as-nails platformer. And what would you expect, considering that this is not only an homage to the Nerd, but also to the frustratingly difficult and poorly-designed games that he's played over the years. But therein lies the mastery in this game. A good parody should include the things that made the subject awful, but without actually being awful itself. It's a challenge, but AVGNA pulls it off without breaking stride.

I mean, it's not perfect. Most of the stages contain a number of the same enemies, only reskinned to suit that stage. Which, of course, is all part of the big parody. But the invincible things that fly in infinite circles start to get pretty tired by the end.

Also, the final boss will rock your world. Difficulty is gradual in the game. You can play the stages in any order you want (and can revisit completed ones, if you so choose), but if you play them in the order they appears on the stage select screen, you will find a pleasant steady increase in difficulty as you go. That said, the final boss was much tougher than anything else I faced. I got him eventually. But man did that take FAR more tries than any obstacle before it.

The music is great, and whatever you hear perfectly suits the situation you're hearing it over. The game is visually appealing and colorful. Controls are responsive, which is a must. The Nerd shoots as fast as you can tap the button, meaning speedier button mashers will have an easier time with most of the bosses (if I had just gotten two more taps in, I could have killed the first boss during his very first vulnerable period). The four different characters (three of whom must be unlocked) each have their uses, and I found myself using each one in different situations over the course of the game. There could be more powerups. By my count, there are four, and one of those can ONLY be used by the Nerd himself.

Also, you get to kill Navi 10/10GOTYAY

reviewText: An excellent platformer. The controls are solid, the levels are semi-varied/creative, the music is flawless, and the secrets are satisfying to find. It is a borderline rage game on the first playthrough, though, as there are a lot of tightly timed maneuvers that'll cause you to die and feel as though you were gypped. The bosses are a tad lackluster, too, as they follow the traditional NES format and have a really, REALLY predictable pattern, with a form of artificial difficulty coming from the speed the boss moves at, and the tight space you have to maneuver in.\n\nIt's definitely worth its price, though. A very nice platformer for this generation, on par with Shovel Knight.
