reviewText:
$15 maybe a bit much, maybe $10 or less is a better price for what it is.

The game should really appeal to anyone who likes the AVGN videos and maybe only them. People who don't like the comedy style of AVGN or don't know him will probably just get annoyed with the game and the story as a whole. There is swearing everywhere but its just text, there is no voice in this game and the story is told via text boxes with drawn art cards depicting scenes at the start of the game and the end. Honestly, story is negligible and really isn't to the concern of the player in these sorts of games. Its all about gameplay.

You play as the nerd or one of four characters you can find. You can hot swap between these characters and some may make situations easier but in all honesty all you need to beat the game is the Nerd and Guitar Guy. The nerd being perfectly fine with all situations aside from those the Guitar Guy is required. Each character has their own special stats/move so you can have some choice about how you accomplish a goal. But for the most part their is really only one way to get by most obstructions. Jump a second to soon or late and you die or get hit. This is to be expected with this type of game but it does get annoying as you progress and insta death blocks become more and more common.

Oh yeah, insta death blocks. Some of the biggest bs to ever grace this game and they are everywhere. I mean EVERYWHERE. They are just plain overused, like the dev couldn't figure out how to give a fair new challenge to the player so they just tossed insta death blocks in everywhere they could which is especially painfull as you get more and more stuff on screen and you have to pay attention to all of it to keep from getting hit. Once you figure out when to jump, run, or whatever it stops being such a challenge unless a glitch or so messes you up.

What I found is the game has really strange hit detection. Sometimes things that clip into your character don't hit you (enemy attacks or insta death stuff) but sometimes you can be not even near it seemingly and it kills you. Exactly how close you can be to something before it kills you is something I still havn't figured out. It just seems like luck that you live or die, especially in the last insta death dissappearing and reappearing block puzzle. You just have to keep trying over and over until it lets you through. Of course skill does come into play but I can't tell you how many times I thought I was in the clear only to have the blocks appear and instakill me although I know I was clear of them. Its complete bull. This same problem can happen with platforms but it seems to be limited to falling platforms I think. You can jump and get stuck on the corner and then the platform falls.

Bouncing is a game of luck aswell. You can try and get good at it but even when you think you have it down your character desides to take a suicide dive straight into insta death. Its like playing with fire while soaked in gas, you have to have the patience of a saint and a surgeon in one to do it right.

Controls are solid aside from the bouncing mechanic which is like the wheel of misfortune. Your character controls very smoothly and solidly aside from times when you need to do jumps perfectly on a single block with an instadeath right beside your intended jump spot. At times like that its easy to overjump and die or under and fall to your demise but this maybe also something to do with the weird hit detection. I really wish I would have recorded it in slow motion to see exactly what was up.

Bosses are a pleasant challenge and once you figure out there pattern they are pretty easy, but thats after you die a good number of times though. Fred Fuchs, the final boss, is an absolute pain in the rear as he is right after the most horrible level in the game. Once you get past beginners traps and turtle your way to the end you will have no lives, but even with knowing the level well you might only get to him with 20 lives and let me tell you that you'll probably need them. What I did was crouch on the lowest right platform and when I could I would jump up and shoot him as he flew up until  he brought out his balls. When hes got his balls out (hehe) crouch on the left side of the platform when hes flying to the left side of the screen, and when he flies to the right side of the screen get on the left sideof the middle platform and crouch. When he starts crapping on you you have to pause the game to see if he is going to ♥♥♥♥ above you, then you have time to react and dodge him. I would advise shooting at him while hes above you then pausing fast as you can when under him. It seems like cheating, but honestly since the crap is random its fair in my opinion. When he brings out his wrecking balls or chain balls (whatever the heck you call them) get on the two platforms farthest to the left.

There you go, Freds dead baby!

Powerups are fairly rare and and theres only 4 types, beer for health, the SNES gun, mecha jesus, and the glitch gremlin. The gun sucks because in one hit you lose it, and the gremlin is mostly useless as it only stops enemies and fire balls and similiar dangers like that from moving. It dousn't make them stop damaging you so its pretty useless aside from points where you get lucky and you line everything up so you can run through an area without getting hit at all. Mecha jesus kills everything on screen and is only really used around where he can be picked up.

The game is pretty goofy, just like AVGNs style but people who arn't familiar with this may become offput by that comedic style. But its all taken from the show and I even chuckled out loud when I saw some of the enemies, text, and levels in general. They nailed AVGN, maybe a bit to well.

The graphics are farily nice and colorfull. Not as good looking as Bastion, but still good looking. The music is also good stuff. I can't remember if its the same song throughout the game as I was to focused on playing the game. Which I think goes to show the music is good if it didn't annoy me and helped me keep my head in the game.

Another bad point is the acheivements, I don't think its possible to get them all. YOLO seems impossible and impossible seems masochistic. I died over a 1,000 times but I had to play through the game twice. Oh yeah, twice! Not even on purpose. I wanted to see other difficulties and without thinking and half on accident I pressed new game but I didn't select a difficulty. The stupid game deleted my save. THIS WAS IN A NERD VIDEO! This was one of the most basic things and they screwed it up. You have one save file and nothing else but you can go in and edit he save file I think in order to skip parts in the game. I didn't do this because I didn't feel like cheating and possibly disabling acheivments since I just don't know what it would do to them.

In summary and TL:DR

AVGNA is a rather good game with alot of throwbacks to the old games featured in AVGN. Unfortunately it is somewhat flawed in some very annoying ways and takes to many of the things that just ♥♥♥♥ gamers and AVGN off and puts them in this game. Its much better though than most 2d Platformer games around these days as instead of trying to be someing silly like art it just tries to be a fun video game and succeeds for the most part. But technical hitches here and there do creep up at times and can be very annoying when they do but its hardly a constant problem.

It can be very challenging, but also very rewarding when you do finally beat a level and eventually the game. The only really big issues are hit detection (because when it does creep up and become a problem you can waste several lives with it) and some of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t jumps or puzzles that are just stupidly difficult. The game is pretty goofy, just like AVGNs style but people who arn't familiar with this may become offput by that comedic style. For better or worse they took everything from the show.

reviewText: He's the angriest gamer you've ever heard, and this game will make damn sure of that. AVGN Adventures takes everything you hate about your favorite classic video game titles such as Castlevania, throws it in your face and ♥♥♥♥♥ down your throat. Fans of AVGN will recognize cameos from famous youtubers as well games that The Nerd has reviewed. You can play as The Nerd at the beginning and unlock three other secret characters throughout the game.  This game is pretty damn hard, seriously. Still, while the game is challenging, it's '♥♥♥♥ing asstastic' in the best way possible. The levels start off mellow (In an extremely hard sort of way) and work its way up to eyeball ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ asstits insane! You'll want to take a ♥♥♥♥ on your controller and shove it up a unicorn's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ after trying to get through some of this game. The music is badass and the art/level design is pretty nice to look at and play through. Don't feel discouraged though, once you know what you're doing and memorize the stages, you'll do fine. What are you waiting for? To fans of AVGN or any hardcore classic gamers, grab your money and play the Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures now! Shitballs.

reviewText:
I bought this game for 0,79€/$1 on Humble Store because some ppl recommended it, thought it would be lame, but ended up enjoying it. This is a really nice game, a mix between some troll platformer game and a normal platformer game.

Story is nothing special just some nerds being teleported inside the games they used to play making them face all the things they did there. The main thing is all the funny parody of other popular game genres.

In this game your hearts are how much beers you drank, maximum 3, you have 3 difficulties to play on in which depends up to how much lives you have, several secrets characters(aka nerds) and 8 levels based on popular game genres, parodying all the funny things gamers referred there, including ironic game names. When you die a funny message appears like laughing of the quotes ppl used to say when they die in the game, insulting everyone and the game itself.

Forgot to mention, this game is HARD!!!

reviewText: I get angry (no pun intended) kinda quicky when a game frustrates me. And while AVGN Adventures did at first, it quickly became one of my favorite indie platformers ever. While I'm not the biggest fan of AVGN, it's quite interesting to see a game with his type of humor. Controls are tight, graphics are appealing to the eye, sundtrack is great, and the game is quite solid overall. It's like Mega Man in that you can choose any level in a non linear order. While the game is difficult, practice makes perfect, and there are harder difficulty options that will make you pull your hair out (I don't know how anyone could beat YOLO mode). Overall, I really enjoy this game. Short enough to replay a lot, fun to play, and pretty solid game overall. I'll give it an 8/10.

reviewText:
In honour of the upcoming release of AVGN: The Movie, I decided to tackle this one.

I'll make it short, partially because the game is also rather short. The game will last you about 4-6 hours, depending on how good you are at platformers, This game is very similar to Megaman 3 when it comes to control, flow, and level design, but even more difficult. If you don't like to die a lot, then a game that is easy to get an achievement for dying 1000 times isn't for you.

The game lets you shoot in all directions, except down for some reason. This is a nit-pick worthy note to me, as he does claim to put elements of all his favourite side-scrollers together, which one of them is Super Castlevania 4.

All the great AVGN moments are referenced, with the Couch / Guitar guy, Bull-♥♥♥♥ Man and even Mike Matei, James' best friend and co-worker, being playable. reviewText: I hate this game. It's really short, really repetitive and WAY TOO HARD. The enemies that you find in each level are all the exact same enemy but with a different look, and the music isn't very good. And the randomized rants at the game over screen are also really repetitive. The controls are also really unresponsive sometimes and really hard to play with unless you're using a controller. And, whenever you change the controls, you have to set them again after you quit the game! It's really annoying! My reccomendation is to get it when it's free or SUPER on sale. Like, 30 cents sale. This game is not worth your time or your money. 2/10.

reviewText: There are a lot of tough platformer games out there presently. Mostly indie games. What makes this game stand out is its very hard difficulty and all the old school games and style of gameplay that you loved when you were a kid playing your hand me downed Nintendo Entertainment System playing Castlevania or Megaman, and this game lets you relive all of the monstrosity from the things you hated about all of the old, tough, challenging NES games. If you aren't a fan of the Nerd then don't really invest in it because you wouldn't get most of the references then. Move on to the next indie platformer.

reviewText:
AVGN Adventures is a game I have been waiting for a long time. I have heard mixed reviews on the game but I would like to interject my ideas and likes about this game. As well as my dislikes.

First of all, the game was designed to be a challenge, a hard game, designed from the AVGN's experiences with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games he had played on various consoles. As one would think, this game is more geared to those who are fans of the AVGN, to those who arent, they wont do so well with this game and will get angry fast.

I'm not saying just non-fans would get mad, I did too at times but I found it funny. I felt the Nerds pain with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games and this was it. The game is unfair, very hard, challenging, and unforgiving on some accounts and that is why I like the game.

The inside jokes are awesome, if you are a fan of the AVGN like me, you would see all the jokes and laugh at them. Even the final level is a whole joke. Though to be fair that level is hard as balls.

I dont recommend this game to those who arent fans of the AVGN, and I would recommend it to AVGN fans but if you are fan, you most likely bought it already.

reviewText:
Наконец-то Нёрд показал, что может не только языком чесать и ругать чужое, но взять и сделать своё. В игре куча камео и отсылок (по большей части собственно к собственным эпизодом), красочная пиксель-арт графика, ошизительнейшая 8-битная музыка, хоть и сортирный, но юмор и... Дикая сложность! Всё, что нёрд критиковал в своих обзорах - от врагов убивающих с одного удара и делающих лайфбар бессмысленным до фирменного Каслваниевского и Ниндзя Гайденовского подлого отскока назад при удара.
Главное, что удалось Джеймсу - полностью передать атмосферу игр на которых многие (в том числе и я) выросли, при этом показав, что даже самые отстойные элементы геймплея могут улыбать при правильной дозировке.
---
Finally Nerd shows us that not only he's true master of dipping ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games made by others into more ♥♥♥♥, but also able to create a decent game himself. There are lot of cameos and references in the game, great pixel-art, awesome 8-bit stylish music and although grotesque, but nice sence of humor and it is... HARD BALLS DIFFUCULT! Everything Nerd critisized in his reviews is in the game - from one-shotting obstacles that pretty much render your life bar obsolete to patented" Castlevania and Ninja Gaiden style backwards jump when you get hit.
The greatest thing James Rolfe and developers have accomplished is a true representation of those games we grew up with and that even most ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gameplay elements can make us laugh when used just right.
Awesome"

Mediocre as a game.

Buy only if you're an AVGN fan.  Otherwise you're far better off elsewhere.

reviewText: A rage game in every aspect, but the Nerd is all about rage, so it fits perfectly. I love all things AVGN, James Rolfe, and Cinemassacre, and this game just reminds me of how awesome they are. Fast paced and addicting gameplay, one of the best 8-bit soundtracks I have ever heard, and more AVGN references than your simple gamer mind can handle. It's more than worth it at the cheap selling price. If you don't buy it, then you're a Laughin' Jokin' Numbnut.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic.

Please pay no attention to my Steam hours here - this is my new Steam account. My old one had over 100 hours in this game when I switched last year, and in total now it's around 200.

The music and difficulty in this game is great. The gameplay is solid and is very similar to how the NES megaman games would play out.

Playing this game on the harder difficulties Hard As Balls+" is a real challenge. Well done to you if you can manage to beat it on any of those
date: without exploting or going back for extra lives. It'll keep you busy for a long time if you set out to complete those.\n\nThis particular game is the one that got me into making my own 2D platformers. I wanted to make custom levels for this game so badly
recommended: but there is no level editor in-game. (And there doesn't need to be really
hoursPlayed: since this is targetting AVGN
voteText:
it wouldn't make all that much sense.)

Here's an example of a custom idea: https://zippy.gfycat.com/DesertedUnpleasantGuillemot.webm

I can't say I'm as involved with it anymore now
helpfulPercent: but it's still a fantastic game overall. If you'd like to test out this game before playing it
votesHelpful: I made a near-direct copy of the tutorial level in HTML5
votesTotal: which you can play in your browser using the link below. It's really funny to compare this to my original version of this
votesFunny:
it shows how awful I was at creating things back then.

https://frisk.itch.io/avgn

AVGNA is well worth a buy if you like old school platformers."

reviewText: Difficulty artificially increased by somewhat weird controls, like you have keep pushing the direction you want to go in while jumping or you fall straight down. Also, instant death blocks, what the hell? Everytime you die you get an unskippable screen with cursewords. Fun the first time, not so much after that. Repeating enemies on all stages, nothing feels unique. Getting the stone powerup causes a big block of text to appear that blocks your view. I thought this would be a good game, good but hard, instead it is a hard game that sucks with nothing to redeem it. There is no sense of accomplishment after getting through an area. The game does feature checkpoints, but they are oddly spaced. Sometimes they are almost next to eachother, sometimes there are so much obstacles between them they might aswell not exist.

reviewText: As an AVGN fan for years, I really wish I could recommend this game. I really do. From The Nerd's death trap from Super Pitfall, to the three spirits of Christmas from the Home Alone episode, you really wouldn't believe the amount of in jokes have been added to the game.\n\nBut I have to look at this from a gamer perspective, and honestly? reviewText: There is a hidden genre of game known only among the hardcore: platform hell." Among its top echelon is the classic
recommended:
which inspired Steam games Super Meat Boy and VVVVVV. Platform Hell games are identified by one simple trait: the game knows what you are about to do, and punishes you for doing something predictable. A cloud mighdisappear as you land on it, for example, or an apple may fall off a tree UPWARDS as you attempt to jump over it.

As a cataloguer of terrible video game tropes, it is natural that the Angry Video Game Nerds includes many, many, surprises in this game. However, AVGN-Adventures is nowhere near as difficult as these other platformers and is slightly less fun.

The Good:

* Awesome level variety harkening back to several classic video games.

* Dozens of allusions, cameos, and references to Angry Video Game Nerd episodes, classic video games, and video game tropes.

* Your character's light-gun changes color depending on the difficulty level. Pink for easy, orange for normal, and gray for  old school." (I was never able to reach one of the higher
hoursPlayed: unlockable difficulty levels).\n\n* Like Nintendo games of yore
voteText:
there are plenty of secrets to find.

* Great use of humor.

* Each level ends with a unique boss from nerd-culture.

* Fantastic pause music.

The Bad:

* The levels are a bit short
helpfulPercent:
although they make up it with their difficulty.

* The "You've got Skill" Steam achievement is duplicated... there are two of them for some reason.

* Control Issue: It is hard to fire your gun to the right if you recently started moving left
votesHelpful: and vice-versa. This becomes very annoying.\n\n* Some enemies
votesTotal: like the reindeer on the snow level
votesFunny: have "magnetism" or something and stay right ON your sprite. since your gun can only fire outwards
commentsCount: it makes them lethal and unfair to fight.\n\n* The game uses the enter key as a pause button
column16: but if you shift+tab out of the game to talk to someone
column17: anytime you hit enter to send your message
column18: the game pauses/unpauses.\n\n* The only level that is truly "really difficult" is the last one
column19:
which is only unlockable after completing all other levels.


The Ugly:

* At times
column20: the game felt more like a chore than a game. I got bored after playing through the first level
column21: but only stuck it out to write this review.\n\n* The game only has a few special items: useless rocks
column24: and mecha Jesus."  (I'm making up my own names for these things
column25: I forgot what they're killed.) I was expecting to discover more items as the game continued
column27:
there are just the four of them.


The Verdict:

* Pick this up if you like AVGN or platformers
column28: but don't expect a rock-solid experience. I personally did not enjoy my time with it."

reviewText:
Get ready, fellow AVGN fans, 'cause this one'll beat you, and call you a B*tch while it's at it.

The overall game is frustrating, but it's the kind of frustrating that makes you beg for more. Each level will test you with Death blocks (Too many of these), enemy placements that are outright D*ckish, and traps you need to understand if you wanna live.

This game is one of the hardest games I ever played, but for right, and wrong, reasons.

But if you're a masochist like I am, then you'll no doubt pick this up somehow, and play it. Beating this game calls for bragging rights.

reviewText:
At first I thought it would be hilarious and decent. Then I played it.
First of all, this game isn't enjoyable. Not only is it so hard that anybody who struggles at completing a single stage from any Mega Man game shouldn't play it, (the difficulty didn't bother me), but it's just a genuinely BORING game. And that surprised me. I've never been bored playing a platformer, so that should say a lot about the game.
If you are passionate about platformers and love them like I do, chances are this game is going to make you never want to play one again, simply due to how... well, boring it is, when it shouldn't be boring at all.
In other words, boring and difficult (which is only a problem if you're not that good at platformers).
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game quickly loses it charm. It has great controls, but its level design is ♥♥♥♥-poor. There's a difference between being hard but fair (Castlevania, Mega Man) and just being cheap, especially with the kill blocks. When you die, you're presented with a randomly generated slew of cuss words from the Nerd, but that won't hold people off for more than a minute. There are plenty of platformers that are more fun to play than this, though I really wish the level design was better, because that with its perfect controls would just be amazing. It's basically a game that had a lot of potential and failed because they chose to make it hard, not knowing the difference between making something fair and unfair. And I've had plenty of experience with retro-style games (played Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 1 and 3, Mega Man 2 Difficult mode [Can actually speedrun it in about 40 minutes with no game overs, a pretty good record]) so this is coming from someone with experience.

reviewText: If you're not a fan of the AVGN videos then I still think you would enjoy this game if you are into platformers. I expected to hate this game, but I had more fun with it than I predicted. I wasted an entire night playing to beat this game, and the level design and OST are pretty good. However regarding difficulty; most of the deaths in this game are caused by the instant-death blocks. This feels like a cop-out while trying to make this game difficult; although it doesn't feel like an old NES game it's still fun nonetheless.

reviewText:
So after having completed this game on Normal difficulty, I thought it only fair to leave some feedback on it.  Make no mistake: This is one of the hardest games ever.

At its core, Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures (AVGNA for short) is a platform and action game; comparing it to Mega Man is a fair reference.  You carry a simple blaster fasioned after the old Zapper light gun peripheral for the original NES.  You can occasionally pick up a rocket launcher in the design of the old Super NES peripheral, the SuperScope.  The platforming is tougher-than-nails, and very few of the stages are what I might call easy, even after multiple attempts.

The overall atmosphere and level design are very well done.  It's easy to see the retro influence in the stages.  For example, the sky stage features monsters fashioned after the Air Tikkis in Mega Man II; another features a labyrinthine castle-like section clearly inspired by Zelda II: The Adventure of Link.  The enemies in these stages are suitably varied, as well, and much of the game's music is also well done.  From an aesthetic point of view, the designers did a great job.

So now we need to discuss the afore-mentioned difficulty.  I find the challenge in this game to be completely uneven and outright sadistic at times.  The game is clearly meant to be retried over and over and over again; why else would you start out with 30 lives?  You're only ever given three units of health (indicated by beer bottles, of all things...); there is no way to earn more.  You lose a full unit with each hit and can only ever recover one at a time by finding beer bottles within a particular stage.  One-Ups are also extremely scarce.

The old standby of getting hit to become invincible for a couple of seconds works somewhat in this game, as well, though certain hazards ignore your invincibility frames and can still kill you on contact, similar to how spikes ignore invincibility in the original Mega Man.  Often, enemies will hit you and knock you into such a hazard; when hit in this game, you do recoil, whether on the ground or in the air, making it very easy to fall into a pit, as well.  Additionally, if you have picked up the rocket launcher, a single hit from an enemy takes it away; you don't even get to carry it until you lose a life.  Given that it's almost always positioned in a particularly nasty section of a stage, this makes it almost worthless as you are almost guaranteed to lose it as soon as you get it.

The introductory stage is deceptively easy; in fact, I completed it in one life on the very first try.  Once I reached the main part of the game, it took me many tries before I even found a stage I could complete.  You luckily can tackle stages in any order you choose, and you only have to restart a level entirely if you lose all lives within it.  For the most part, the checkpoints are plentiful enough that you rarely have to repeat lengthy sections, and you always restart at a checkpoint when you die, provided you have lives remaining.

One of the problems I found with the game, however, is with collision detection.  Even this is somewhat uneven; sometimes, you can get right up on a hazard, such as the skull blocks, but other times, having even a single pixel touching a hazard is death.  I found this to be particularly true with the Rainbow Beams in the final level; many times, I couldn't even TELL I had a pixel within range of one, then suddenly found myself exploding in bloody death.  Play control also seemed tepid sometimes.  I would try to turn in one direction only to have the game not respond at all.  My inconsistent experiences with these aspects of the game only added to the overall frustration.

But the primary reason that I can't recommend this game is simply the final boss.  It is almost without question the most unfair boss battle I have ever played in a game (I'll revisit this opinion once I finally complete Dark Souls I'm sure...).  Even after I learned his patterns and put myself in the best position possible for the first couple of phases, his brutally strong defense, the trap-filled lair, and the near-impossible climax to the battle forced me to waste literally HUNDREDS of lives before I could finally win.  I ultimately felt that after all the time I had put into learning the individual stages and even being able to get to his lair within a reasonable number of lives, the effort was wasted as the final boss just decimated me again and again and again.  I feel like a small amount of luck was involved in the run that was ultimately successful.  I'm relieved that I never have to fight him again.

Another big issue I had was with random crashes.  I experienced more than a few during my playthrough, and all sent me back to the Windows Desktop.  This happened several times when I reached the boss of a level, or after I had managed to finally get through a particularly difficult section with many lives left in reserve, forcing me to do everything over again.  It even happened in the final stage after a particularly good run through the first few sections.  I would say I experienced roughly 10 such crashes.  Given that most games I play rarely, if ever, crash, this ended up being another obstacle to completing it.

If it weren't for the random crashes, and if it weren't for the almost impossible final boss, I could give this game at least a cautious recommendation.  But when the final challenge of the game makes everything you've done up to then feel pointless, that's when it goes from just a hard-core challenge to something more masochistic in nature.  After awhile, it just stopped being fun to try and overcome it.  As it is, I can only recommend this to the hardest-core gamers of this genre.  Just be prepared to want to break your controller in half.

5.5 / 10

reviewText:
References! Cursing! Self-depreciation! Toilet humour! It's FUNNEH!

I gotta be honest: To my knowledge, I’ve never watched anything related to ‘AVGN’. If you like this stuff, good on you! But after seeing the writing in this game, I doubt it’s for me. Different tastes and all.

Still, this game suffers greatly from “Claptrap syndrome”. You see, Borderlands’ Claptrap is annoying on purpose, but he is still. Really. ♥♥♥♥ing. Annoying. Most of the time. This game’s writing, references, and humour are so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ [and I do hope, on purpose] -- and downright hate-filled [if you hate this kind of thing so much, why do exactly the same?] -- that even good platforming could probably not help it. And here comes the kicker, it doesn’t have good platforming either. You might want to fool yourself and call it “hard”, but this is not the ‘Super Meat Boy’ or ‘They Bleed Pixels’ good-and-hard kind of hard, it’s just the pretty-bad-and-thus-hard kind of hard.

If you’re not a fan of ‘AVGN’, best stay away.

reviewText:
I have nearly 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews - Game 9
Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures
Purchase Date: 8/25/2014

The first splash screen I see is Rated F for ♥♥♥♥balls".  I did not realize at the time what valuable information I was being given.

The first thing I realize is
date: this game is clearly intended to be played with a controller.  The main menu flashes "PRESS START".  After some quick trial and error
recommended: I figured out that the Enter key means start.  After a couple of quick screens to explain the story (such as it is)

voteText: jump
helpfulPercent: and shoot your way through the level.  It didn't take me long to die due to a mistimed jump
votesHelpful: which caused me to fall through the floor.  That means instant death in this game.  You also have a number of beers
votesTotal: which you can think of like hearts in a Zelda game.  Every time you hit something bad
votesFunny: you'll lose a beer.  If you lose all of your beers then you die
commentsCount: and get sent back to the last checkpoint.\n\nIt became very clear that the game intends for me to die.  A lot.  Every time I die

column17: you start to get his point.\n\nThe graphics and sound are fine
column18: and do a good job of evoking the retro feel the game goes for.  It does look and sound like a game you would have played on the old NES.  Which I think is also the point of the insane difficulty as well.  I should mention
column19: the game does give you a choice of difficulty
column20: so there is an "Easy" mode.  But it doesn't really make a difference.  Easy mode just means you get unlimited continues and more beer.  But more beer doesn't keep you from missing a jump and dying.  A lot.\n\nOnce I made it through the tutorial level
column21: I was presented with a list of levels to choose from.  I appreciated the fact that I could make the choice myself
column22: and the game wasn't completely linear.  Each level has a different theme.  For example one level is based on Castlevania
column23:
and contains a lot of the same traps and fiends you'd expect to see in a Castlevania game.  Another level is based on D&D and has an appropriately fantasy theme.

I do have to give props to the workmanship put into the game.  I think it took a lot of work to make a game this hard.  The level design is very good in that regard.

I only ended up playing about 40 minutes of this game.  After sampling a few levels
column24: I realized I didn't need to play any longer to understand what I was in for.\n\nUltimately I can't recommend this game.  But I want to be clear that the reason I'm not recommending the game isn't because of it's difficulty
column25:
but rather I think it has a limited appeal.

You should buy this game if you are:

*15 years old

*A fan of the Angry Video Game Nerd

*Are looking for a video game to take you back to the days of throwing your controller at the TV when you were trying to get past that level in Battletoads.


If you are not any of these things

reviewText:
If you're into challenging platformers (e.g. Megaman, Castlevania and Mario), this is one to look out for. The graphics are pretty sweet and the music is awesome. The control is good and unique in its way, comparable to Mario, but slightly stiffer. Be warned for very frustrating level design. Fortunately, there are many many checkpoints on the way and you get 30 lives to start with. That should give you a good idea of how this game is designed and I like it a lot.

The reason for not recommending this game is because of technical issues. This game does not play well on a keyboard so I highly recommend using a controller, but besides the Xbox 360-controller, getting standard Windows controllers up and running is way too hard to do and required the use of third-party software, plus there's a bug that introduces 8 seconds load time after every death when using the controller, which is horendous. These are issues that were mentioned a lot in the forums, so I am not the only one. As such, even though the game is fun and creative, I cannot recommend a game that is technically underdeveloped. I have tested version 1.7.1 from february 2014.

Other than that, this game begs to be played on a tv with a controller in your hand, rather than on a PC. I would like to encourage the developers to make it run natively under SteamOS. This is one of those games that would benefit from an open console platform.

reviewText: AVGN Adventures should have been a good game, and on first impression, it looks, feels, and plays like one, but you eventually realise it's just a generic rage game made in flash that you have to pay for. All the levels have extremely poor and repeatitive design, with practically nothing but death block after death block after death block filling all the levels. However, visually, the game does look very nice, with all the levels having different appeals and themes. The music is pretty good too, and the game makes lots of references to past AVGN episodes, except they stop being funny very quickly.\nIn short, don't buy this. Go google 'rage games' and click one. It's the same thing.

reviewText: I can't recomend this game to anyone really and mainly cause I couldn't beat it. Got all the way to the final @#$%ing level and face the final boss with 20+ lives lost all of them tried it again and did this until I hated myself. the problem is in general the bosses in AVGN adventures are so poorly designed that it really sours the feeling of the supposed hard but never unfair BS. All of the bosses and I do mean all of use a figure eight patten maneuver and it never feels very well planned out in fact the exact routes always feel random other than its a @#$%ing figure eight you got nothing else to go off of. Most of the bosses are passable and least somewhat forgivable for this crap until you play the cheep @$% final boss than your basically like @#$% this not like there a goddess getting ready to blow me if I beat this @#$%ing thing. I actually enjoyed most of the rest of the game the levels are hard as @#$% yes and their all trial and error but so is megaman the difference why I actually got through these levels I guess because on normal you do have 30 lives. I have heard that there's a YOLO difficulty which is exactly what it sounds like and I don't want to even imagine what that's like. however at the end if the day I guess the question is can one boss, even the final one, ruin a game for you so much that your just like @#$% this game? Well it did for me don't buy this unless your really into masochism even more so than Dark Souls (which is a hard @#$ game I did actually beat), do buy the soundtrack though its @#$%en awesome as hell.

reviewText: i'd rather eat a roadkilled skunk dunked in gasoline lit on fire coated with dirty rocks while being puked on by the nerd, than play this crappy game. Anyway- There's a difference between hard and unfair. If a games hard, that means it's doing its job right, but, if a game is just plain annoying, that means that the devs just didn't really try. Lets take Super-Meat-Boy, for example. The game is hard, but not unfair, because every situation has a solution that can be solved by everyone, regardless of their age. Now, with the AVGN Adventures, it's just plain luck. You have to try 100's of times, and what is worse is the death blocks. They're just there to make the game seemingly harder. The Dragon Boss fight on Thy Farts Consumed would be a pretty hard-ish boss fights, but adding death-blocks? You can shoot the Dragon, sure, but you gotta move constantly, trying to fight him.  Waste of $10.

reviewText:
This is not a good game.

The controls are very loose, the level design is not smart. This was not developed well, and I think that there was a disconnect between the Nerd and the develpers. I'm sure James Rolfe (The Nerd) is not completely satisfied with this game, as it is far from great. However, fans have wanted a game for a long time and he had to start promoting himself and things going on in the meantime like his movie. It is not funny, unlike the Nerd's videos. I love AVGN, and I picked this game up on a humble bundle. I am glad I did not pay full price for it. I am not angry or disappointed, I didn't expect much.

It's worth pointing out that this game adds nothing to the lore, it doesn't add any value to the AVGN brand. You are not missing out on anything if you pass on this game.

Do not buy this game.

reviewText: An all around decent platformer. However, the game's forced sense of humor and overuse of profanity seems excessive even for media featuring the AVGN. every few seconds the character makes a comment (though highly distracting text in mid-gameplay) about some overused gameplay or setting trope. Every death you have to sit through a long, unskippable rant about how awful the Nerd finds this world before you can retry. And after a half hour the crude humor loses it's charm and starts to get grating.\nIt has some nice nods to the AVGN web series and the platforming provides a decent challenge, but the humor gets old pretty quick.

reviewText:
Many people enjoy a nice challenge, many folks enjoy the Angry Video Game Nerd. Creating a game about the Angry Video Game Nerd seems like the next step in breaking the AVGN brand into a new medium seems like a natural progression. The end result, however, just ends up being a dull and charmless. The worst of it, just being downright dull.

The best way to take a look at the game would just be to start up at the top with the man whom the title is named after. The majority of the comedy of the AVGN is in his delivery, his facial expressions, and over the content of the game. That gets lost when the extent you see of his anger is a simple This game is a bunch of diahrea ♥♥♥♥ coming out of a rabbits ♥♥♥♥." readout in a slow text. It is true that a majority of the nerd's history is present in the game but it suffers the problem of being a reference alone without really adding much of anything unique to the game. (i.e. The Robot Jesus Christ being a general screen clearing attack.)

This extends to the game itself
date: while it's true you'll find a challenge here that isn't part of the problem. Challenge in itself can be dealt with if the core of the game itself is interesting and fun to play and that simply doesn't apply here. Across a generic song backdrop the game it plays almost exactly like run and gun flash game you play on the internet with generic challenges
recommended: all the while reading Angry Video Game quips slowly sprawled across the screen. The problem I had with the game itself was the challenges to the game being repeated ("Skull deathtraps") with each stage being a homage without doing anything really different to the formula that changes the game up in any reasonable manner.\n\nIt strikes of an idea that sounds interesting in paper but not in practice. Angry Video Game Nerd playing all of his past games he's slammed? Sounds like a reasonable and interesting idea. Playing the stages without varying the levels up to a significant degree? That's when the game starts going downhill. What could've been an interesting formula just descends into a dull  and unexciting game that doesn't really justify spending the higher spending price. Angry Video Game Nerd fans will be mildly amused by the nods present in the game but as a whole the Nerd's style of humor doesn't translate well into text form leaving them dissapointed. People looking for a challenge will be turned off by the overall dull game play and design despite the colorful stages offering no incentive to continue playing. I'd skip this even if you are a huge fan of the Nerd."

reviewText:
This game is a love letter to video games that were frustratingly difficult to win.
If you miss games like Ninja Gaiden and Mega Man (the first one), you will love this game. Rote is essential to defeating the levels, and trust me, you'll get lots of repetition in trying to figure out where the surprise monsters will pop out at you next. What fun!

The default controls on a keyboard are abysmal, but you can reconfigure them easily.
If you're looking for a legitimate throwback to an era that doesn't need to come back, this is your game.

Note: I did not finish this game, or even a single level beyond the tutorial. I don't ever plan on revisiting it.

reviewText: If the game's purpose is to infuriate players, then by all means it succeeds. It's a really sloppy platformer with blind drops, traps specifically placed after some checkpoints to make you wait a couple of seconds, pretty buggy (you glitch through moving platforms), and generally feels like a horribly incestuous child of Metroid and Mega Man.\n\nIf you too want to become an angry video game nerd, play this game. If you value quality in platformers, go elsewhere. Christ.

reviewText: This may be the hardest game I've ever played, and though it's fun, I have a hard time recomending it.  Mechanically, it has a lot in common with classic NES Mega Man, but the dificulty curve is through the roof.  Its designed to be nearly unbeatable, except through reptition and learning to beat a level the hard way, much like super meat boy.  The art and music are great if you appriciate 8/16 bit era looks and sounds and there are lots of nods to both nerdy culture and classic games that any retro game fan is sure to love.  Sadly, the game is too lude and crude for its own good... It doesnt' try to be witty and instead hopes that you'll find tastless nonsince amuseing, but I didn't.  I'm sure the humor will appeal to someone, but not me, and it will likely appal the average person.  If you love dificult, retro stylized games and can enjoy or ignore course and disguesting content, you'll love this game, especially considering its low price point!  Sadly, for the average gamer looking for old school platformer thrills, i'd have to suggest you instead look to polished, longer, less offensive games like cave story+, super meat boy or rayman.

reviewText:
AVGN is back! Or so.. we thought. Game which is made official by Game Trailer themselves [and some other dev i guess]. Game  story is all about Nerd and his friends trying to get out from the world of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Video Game which sucked them right at the beggining. Is AVGN Adventures game is good or atleast passable? NO! But did it succeded? YES! Indeed the game is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ but that's the whole point. This game teaches you how games were back in a day, hard or really frustrating, though those are the good sides but game got it's own ammount of problems.

+Good Visuals, 8-bit themed like it's 80's NES era all over again.
+Music is great too, they are like more clearly arranged tracks. Nostalgia is all over the place.
-There is literally no story in this game, nerd get's sucked into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game and tries to escape, that's it.
-Glitches everywhere, oh and i'm not talking about glitch gremlin here. For instance i hope they will atleast fix the achievements.
-Poor character skills and controlls, Mike is a worst character in the game, poor range and his way of finding secrets is a joke. You will beat this game as a Nerd anyway, there is absolutely no point to these characters.

Final Verdict: 5.0 Mediocre [Will NOT recommend for full price, and if you're AVGN fan.. I guess you bought the game anyway]

reviewText: This game is insane. That is all the explanation I can give. Of course, I'll elaborate. It is insanely hard, so casual gamers beware. It is also insanely funny, and the randomly generated quotes almost make me want to die in the game. The best part of this game, however, is the music. On a scale of 1 to 10, music gets a 59.5. I am dead serious. This game is great for the hardcore gamer and at a good price, too. If you're looking for a real challenge, try normal or old school difficulty!

reviewText:
I was kinda skeptical about this game at first to be honest until I played it at Pax and actually really had fun with it, after playing the full game I can say that it’sFard  (fun/Hard) dude. But the game controls perfectly with a controller, I haven’t tried it on a keyboard but honestly I don’t want to.
the controls are so tight and responsive that if you mess up you know it’s on you, the difficulty is just that perfect level of nes hard and by that I mean it’s challenging and you’ll die tons but the more you figure the game out, the easier you’ll be able to get through the level.

all of the levels are in one way or another a reference to James’ work and if you’ve watched the Nerd religiously like I have it’s a real delight to see all the references to not only his videos but other games as well.

I love the art style but there were a few enemies that really stood out and seemed out of place in comparison to a lot of other ones but that’s kind of minor and doesn’t really take away from the experience at all.

The music is AMAZING and I especially love the boss theme with the AVGN theme mixed into it as well as the level complete song which is always incredibly satisfying to hear.

This game really gives a good chunk of replayability with all the hidden easter eggs to find as well as unlocking additional and harder difficulties to challenge yourself on.

I can actually easily say even people who aren’t familiar with the Nerd would probably really enjoy this game for it’s old school platformer challenge.

With all that said, my final rating is this:

It ♥♥♥♥ing sucks it sucking ♥♥♥♥s it ♥♥♥♥ing blows and I don’t like it. 5outta5

reviewText:
Fantastic. Exactly what you'd expect from a modern-day platformer game.

Fluid control, vivid and fluent graphics, awesome 8-bit-style music, precise hit judgement, excellent level design. Just perfect. It is hard, but as the Nerd says, you don't die because the game cheats. This is a fair challange.

Sadly I'm not so good at this kind of game and only played through the easiest difficulty where there are unlimited lives. Even this is pretty challenging for me. Took tens of minutes to defeat the final boss. But when I did defeat him, man was that satisfying. I believe the higher difficulties will challenge even the most hardcore players.

WTF I only have 1 hour on record? I did clear all stages once. Maybe it's because I mostly played offline.

+ you are the f**king NERD!
+ lots of gags from the nerd videos
+ oldschool 8-bit graphics and music
+ unlimited continue
+ fluent control
+ challenging bosses
- in easy difficulty the powerups are of no use
10 out of 10, masterpiece.

reviewText:
This game is put together pretty well, with great music and good controls. If you're a fan of the AVGN series you'll get the references in the game, although they get old pretty fast.

The level design, however, will leave you with urges to look up the programmer's address so you can wait casually outside of his house, then when he leaves to get some groceries you bash his face in with a baseball bat. It has been designed to infuriate you.

It's a terrible, but awesome nostalgic feeling. I haven't felt this angry playing a videogame in at least 10 years. Invite some friends over, pour a few drinks (you'll need them), and be sure to have a pillow or something to punch. But be warned, this is not a fun" game."

reviewText: while i'm a fan of AVGN, this game really is just a compilation of the Nerd's misadventures with bad games. the platforming is tight and the nerd and co. control nicely... for the most part. my main problem is those cheap death blocks, you can argue it makes the platforming more difficult, but it defeats the purpose if you have enemy placements to hit you anyways, and you have a minor hitback and when a death block is near game over. again, maybe that was the intent but it's very annoying and cheap majority of the time. that said, its a solid platformer and it adds something new in each stage. would i recommend this game? only if you're a fan of AVGN this yes, but as a game, it's average nothing special. if you're determined you can beat the game within 4-5 hours. so if you want a good platforming shooter, this is a good game to kill some time.

reviewText: A rage-quit game that stands toe-to-toe with Super Meat Boy in terms of difficulty, AVGN Adventures is a challenge straight out of the crap games we got stuck playing as kids.  This whole game is a big inside joke about the AVGN series, so if you're not familiar with it, you won't understand any of this.  For the rest of you, this is a cute and vulgar companion to the series.\n\nMy only gripe is the lack of native controller support.  This game MUST be played with a controller, so for support to be left off is a real drag.  There are third-party programs that can compensate for this, but it shouldn't be necessary.

reviewText:
A fun side scrolling wonder which truely takes you back to the past.
Combines difficult platforming with wonderful retro graphics and smooth gameplay.
For regular gamers seeking a good game this is the one but for anyone who is a fan of the Nerd, it is a must have.
Featuring many things that made the Nerd we all love including characters like the Glitch Gremlin and Super Mecha Death Christ.
So in short a fun addictive game with a lot to offer but not for anyone who is expecting a simple walk in the park.

reviewText: Based on the legendary online reviewer by the same name, created and played by James Rolfe, AVGN Adventures is a delightfully retro 2D romp. Clearly, this game was designed to appeal to casual gamers as well as AVGN fans. The controls are very responsive and easy to pick up (I would argue, for all its simplicity, it's some of the best controls I've ever used), and, despite what many have said, the difficulty is balanced fairly, sitting on that line between easy and frustratingly hard to provide healthy challenge. Compare this to say, Worms Revolution or Pokemon Battle Revolution (nominal similaraties purely coincidental), where much of the challenge comes from how unfairly rigged the game and the AI are against you, and you can appreciate how good a game this is. As a fan of the Nerd myself, I also enjoyed the sheer volume of references and characters crammed into the game, and the many cameos from other reviewers (though no JonTron, Spoony, Yahtzee or Nostalgia Critic? REALLY?). The music is also fun to listen to and has a lot of variety. The main complaint I have with this game is also a warning: if you miss a level-specific achievement, you can't replay a level you've already completed or start a new game to go back and do it without your old file being erased. This caused some frustration and anger with me when I started a new game to complete the No
date: you listen!" achievement in the tutorial level
recommended: only to then realise that the game had replaced my old save file. Given the simplicity of the game
hoursPlayed: a better saving system really wouldn't have been difficult to do. As a final note
voteText: gamers who aren't followers of the Nerd won't get the references (then again
helpfulPercent: would you really buy this game is you weren't a fan?). A great game
votesHelpful: and very addictive."

Secondly, ♥♥♥♥ THIS GAME. There are far too many instant kill blocks, spikes, and especially on the mario themed level, those little spike blocks and all go suck a ♥♥♥♥. I would reccomend this game to people who are very good with an xbox controller or a gamepad, as it cannot be easily played on a keyboard.

This is a game full of challenge, which is why i understand as to why people would like it, the same way dark souls works, when you complete a level, you feel on top of the world.

Honestly, I would reccomend this game, but only if you are very familiar with a gamepad, like a lot of challenge all throughout the game, and can recall every reference from the AVGN episodes.

Overall, I give this game a 5/10, a good game, with major flaws.

Buy to bulk up your library, do NOT expect to complete it.

reviewText:
AVGN Adventures is a total recommend if, and only if, you like your games bloody hard.  I mean, this game is harder than any game in the Ghost n' Goblins / Ghouls n' Ghosts series!

The Game controls really well for the most part, but is a tad too slippery, making platforming not as tight as it needs to be.  This isn't a deal breaker, but it may be a controller breaker.

Highlights:

- The Visuals are incredible by 16 bit goodness standards!
- The Music is the pinnacle of chiptune greatness!
- The Humor and Vulgarity are top notch, making this game a must have for AVGN fans!

Lowlights:

- deathblocks.
- deathBLOCKS.
- DEATHBLOCKS!

If you don't like hard games, or are used to playing games like God of War, this game probably isn't for you.  But if you like the Dark Souls, or the Devil May Cry's, then pick this one up!  You will curse like a sailor and cry like Garrus!

reviewText: When I heard that Steam was selling a game starring James Rolfe the AVGN himself, I didn't know what to think. Personally, I'm more of an Irate Gamer fan (haters please don't spam me a bunch of hate), but since I still do in fact like the AVGN, I decided to check out the game. After playing it, I was amazed. The game takes inspiration from classics such as Mega Man and Castlevania. The graphics, music, nostalgic values, gameplay, humor and replay value were just remarkable. Even if you don't like the AVGN or his videos, I still recommend this game, because its a great stand alone game, even without the AVGN character. My only nitpick with the game is that there are only 10 levels, but the game resembles an NES game, so I'll let that slide. I see myself playing this game a lot in the future, and I won't regret it either. Now if we could only get the Irate Gamer game on Steam, then I would have a match made in Heaven. Thanks for reading this review. Check the game out and decide for yourself :)

reviewText: Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures is a tough side-scrolling platformer coupled with elements of Megaman or Contra. The difficulty curve is much like Ghosts ‘n Goblins that will have you replaying the same areas over and over again. Any fan of AVGN will feel at home with all of the references and inside jokes that are packed into the game. The music is great, the graphics are fun (even with some reskinned images here and there), AVGN Adventures will put you into a fist clenching rage to finish. Difficult platformers are all hype nowadays and AVGN is no different.\n\nhttp://iamericm.com/2014/03/angry-video-game-nerd-adventures-indie-game-review/

reviewText: At first, I bought this game purely to support James Rolfe for being James Rolfe. The first time I played the game I got a little upset with the game for its difficulty. After a few months I gave it another try (both this time and last time on Easy difficulty), and actually beat the game after I sat down and devoted a few hours to the game. Some parts you need to take a breath and gently pass by, and some parts you need to grab your balls and charge. Except on Laughin' Jokin' Numbnuts. You might want to take your sweet time there.\n\nI rate this 8.5/10, because it's a decent game that you should play, regardless if you watch the AVGN or not.

reviewText:
A retro-style platformer that revels in the addictively obnoxious traits that NES fans love. Intentionally vulgar, utterly shameless, and strangely hypnotic. I found it very hard to stop playing once I started.

Difficulty is slightly overblown. Easy and Normal difficulties won't give very many people much trouble thanks to the abundance of lives, infinite continues, and frequent checkpoints. The higher difficulties, however, will scratch that masochist itch of yours if you have one.

Unlike most retro-style indie games, this one is completely devoid of pretentiousness. It's a good Mega Man game with a dirty mouth. All the enjoyment will come from the gameplay and the AVGN fanservice.

If you're not an AVGN fan then some things will go over your head and you won't enjoy the references as much, but the gameplay is still solid.

reviewText: Fard is the best way to describe AVGN Adventures. A spin-off made to p#@s you off. Story-The Nerd and his freinds get sucked into Game Land. Altough the story is basic, the humor  is amazing. Presintation-This game is a retro inspired platformer, but don't be fooled. The music and visuals are stunning. Gameplay-Inspired by Mega Man, this is a run 'n' gun platformer. You can unlock characthers like B.S Man, the now dead Guitar Guy and even Mike! You can get power-ups like Super Mecha Death Christ, Glitch Gremlin, a Super Scope and stones,but one thing I love in AVGN Adventures, It's fun and hard-Fard. So AVGN Adventures is a heck of a good time with a basic plot brilliant visuals, and Fard gameplay. AVGN fans, Hardcore gamers and even non-AVGN fans,will love it my final score is 95/100.

reviewText:
First things first, this game has some kickass music and should be an item of any AVGN fanboy/girl's steam library, the controls are great and the enemies are all things that AVGN followers will recognise.

Secondly, ♥♥♥♥ THIS GAME. There are far too many instant kill blocks, spikes, and especially on the mario themed level, those little spike blocks and all go suck a ♥♥♥♥. I would reccomend this game to people who are very good with an xbox controller or a gamepad, as it cannot be easily played on a keyboard.

This is a game full of challenge, which is why i understand as to why people would like it, the same way dark souls works, when you complete a level, you feel on top of the world.

Honestly, I would reccomend this game, but only if you are very familiar with a gamepad, like a lot of challenge all throughout the game, and can recall every reference from the AVGN episodes.

Overall, I give this game a 5/10, a good game, with major flaws.

Buy to bulk up your library, do NOT expect to complete it.

reviewText:
Funny, full of attitude, and has a classic feel.

This game is definitely a solid reminder of what it was like to play old games on the NES, or at the arcade. You die, you die, you die, you do a little bit better, then you die again. Definitely a rage-inducing game if you're trying to do perfect runs in one sitting. The music is phenominal, the gameplay is tight and responsive, and it has plenty of attitude. Also you get to kill Navi, if you're not buying it for that alone than you are wasting your money.

There isn't much more to say, other than that the game is fairly short if you disclude dying over and over and over again.

reviewText:
Holy butts, this game is awesome!

I've been a fan of the AVGN since he started, and I've met him a handful of times. He's a really cool guy, so I try to support him in any way that I can. When I heard he had his own game, I jumped at the chance to get it.

Simply put, this game is a blast. It's a tough as nails action platformer that perfectly captures the spirit of older gen titles. Kickin' music? Yes. Tight controls? Yes. Colorful, varied stages each with their own theme and challenges? Yes. A play experience that makes me feel like I spent my money well? Yes.

If you remember playing games like Contra, Journey to Silius, Mega  Man, and  Super Turrican, this game is for you. It's a simple premise: shoot and jump your way through each stage, all while collecting power ups and dodging an insane amount of obstacles. That's it. And it works. It's the high level of difficulty that makes this game so good though: a very balanced difficulty system allows players of all skill levels to get what they want from this game.

Aside from the great gameplay, this is also a fantastic low-brow homage to the games of yesteryear. The incessant profanity made me laugh, too.

Buy this game. Expect a torrent of swear words and colorful metaphors to explode from your mouth, but it's a gratifying experience when you finally beat it.

reviewText: Ridiculous platformer that does an excellent job bringing us back to the days of spitting expletives through clenched teeth, gripping controllers to death, sore thumbs, and flailing wildly with frustration. Fantastic music, funny dialogue (though sometimes distracting), unlockable characters, old school cheats, and multiple themed levels. Everything bad about this game is essentially satire of everything we hated about out old NES games, which is why we keep coming back for more. This game morphs you into a gluttion for punishment and you will find yourself coming back for more. Good freaking luck on the final boss is all I can say.

reviewText:
I was kinda skeptical about this game at first to be honest until I played it at Pax and actually really had fun with it, after playing the full game I can say that it’sFard  (fun/Hard) dude. But the game controls perfectly with a controller, I haven’t tried it on a keyboard but honestly I don’t want to.
the controls are so tight and responsive that if you mess up you know it’s on you, the difficulty is just that perfect level of nes hard and by that I mean it’s challenging and you’ll die tons but the more you figure the game out, the easier you’ll be able to get through the level.

all of the levels are in one way or another a reference to James’ work and if you’ve watched the Nerd religiously like I have it’s a real delight to see all the references to not only his videos but other games as well.

I love the art style but there were a few enemies that really stood out and seemed out of place in comparison to a lot of other ones but that’s kind of minor and doesn’t really take away from the experience at all.

The music is AMAZING and I especially love the boss theme with the AVGN theme mixed into it as well as the level complete song which is always incredibly satisfying to hear.

This game really gives a good chunk of replayability with all the hidden easter eggs to find as well as unlocking additional and harder difficulties to challenge yourself on.

I can actually easily say even people who aren’t familiar with the Nerd would probably really enjoy this game for it’s old school platformer challenge.

With all that said, my final rating is this:

It ♥♥♥♥ing sucks it sucking ♥♥♥♥s it ♥♥♥♥ing blows and I don’t like it. 5outta5

reviewText:
Fantastic. Exactly what you'd expect from a modern-day platformer game.

Fluid control, vivid and fluent graphics, awesome 8-bit-style music, precise hit judgement, excellent level design. Just perfect. It is hard, but as the Nerd says, you don't die because the game cheats. This is a fair challange.

Sadly I'm not so good at this kind of game and only played through the easiest difficulty where there are unlimited lives. Even this is pretty challenging for me. Took tens of minutes to defeat the final boss. But when I did defeat him, man was that satisfying. I believe the higher difficulties will challenge even the most hardcore players.

WTF I only have 1 hour on record? I did clear all stages once. Maybe it's because I mostly played offline.

+ you are the f**king NERD!
+ lots of gags from the nerd videos
+ oldschool 8-bit graphics and music
+ unlimited continue
+ fluent control
+ challenging bosses
- in easy difficulty the powerups are of no use
10 out of 10, masterpiece.

reviewText:
For AVGN fans, this game will likely take you back to many of the episodes he reviewed before. For people who don't know who he is, the game is still plenty fun.

This game is done in classic 8bit style, but has the more refined controls of a 16bit game. That being said, get ready for th insane amount of difficulty that comes from those types of games.

Much of the game revolves memorizing certain patterns of the of the enemies of whatever world you're in, and this means that there will be a lot of dying. But, the game is incredibly fair with lives and check points, so you have no true reason to stop trying.

But if you're not a fan of his most, if not all the references will fly straight over your head.

In all, it's a great platformer, in that old symplistic style, but but people unaware of the character it's based on won't uderstand many of the jokes.

7.5/10

reviewText:
AVGN Adventures is a total recommend if, and only if, you like your games bloody hard.  I mean, this game is harder than any game in the Ghost n' Goblins / Ghouls n' Ghosts series!

The Game controls really well for the most part, but is a tad too slippery, making platforming not as tight as it needs to be.  This isn't a deal breaker, but it may be a controller breaker.

Highlights:

- The Visuals are incredible by 16 bit goodness standards!
- The Music is the pinnacle of chiptune greatness!
- The Humor and Vulgarity are top notch, making this game a must have for AVGN fans!

Lowlights:

- deathblocks.
- deathBLOCKS.
- DEATHBLOCKS!

If you don't like hard games, or are used to playing games like God of War, this game probably isn't for you.  But if you like the Dark Souls, or the Devil May Cry's, then pick this one up!  You will curse like a sailor and cry like Garrus!

reviewText:
As a fan of this game, I'd give it a 8/10.
7/10 for the game itself.

The Good: Controls are fluient. Music is in 8-bit and in it's awesome glory. The game's graphics is all in classic 8-bit style that can reflect on the Mega Man games on the NES. The game has hidden cameos of other known internet celeberties and easter eggs. A lot of references reflected to the show. You even have the freedom of choosing which world you want to start off and complete in any order. It maintains the retro feel of playing a NES game that offers the challenge. Higher difficulties offer more challange to those who want to beat the game and make a name for themselves. Just like in past challenging games such as limited lives, removing the save feature, and the use of limited continues to replace the save feature if you plan to full play the game in the harder difficulties. So it has replayability.

The Bad: This game is hard to recomend if you're not a fan or never even heard of who the AVGN is. By playing the harder difficulties and the save feature turned off, you can't quit out the game and lose all your game progress. The game is short and can be finished in about 2 hours. The bosses feel somewhat repeatative and can be predictable when most of them move around the screen in a figure 8 pattern.

I don't have a lot to say for this game. But the game will urge you to play it again time to time. You may have a lot of lives. But they will start to run out fast if you're not too careful. The game has to do with a lot of time and patience if you plan to get through it alive. If you try to speed run the game with no thought, you will die so fast before you can say game over. The hidden characters you find and play as can be useful sometimes to get from a point you can't reach, a hidden wall or passage, and help you out getting a few extra lives and power ups. Although you will be using The Nerd more than any other character when it comes to killing mostt to all enemies and bosses. The game maybe hard. But can make you come back just to beat the harder difficulties to prove you can beat them since the game is short, but sweet. The game recomends you get the full experience by playing it using a controler. The game is really unfriendly to those who use a keyboard. You can rebind the keys, but the jump timings can be hindered just by a bit when it comes to key timing. I don't recomend  buying this game at $15 full price. Wait for the game to go on sale. Still, it's a fun game not to pass up. A good game to play for yourself. But the game is much better when The Nerd plays it. Just like in the words of The Nerd said, It's all my fault! $@%! this game!"

X3"

reviewText: If you have never seen the Angry Video Game Nerd, then stop what you are doing and watch some of his reviews. If you have seen them, then you know exactly what to expect. This game is a recreation of all the most horrible deaths and unfair level designs of the early Nintendo games. It features annoying enemies, near-impossible jumps and more deaths per minute than you can count. It is also funny, full of foul language and has a really awesome soundtrack. It is a cruel game and will appeal to those of us who misses the old school Nintendo torture.

reviewText:
Well, they finally did it.

I wasn't too familiar with the AVGN until recently, when I marathoned episodes after attending James' panel at SGC. This game hits it. Though it'd really suck if it hadn't, considering the amount of attention that ScrewAttack and other related dudes paid to it during development.

Tight controls, vintage level design, and (of course) 'Nerd allusions define this game. With a gamepad, it feels like I'm playing a SNES game that's been inexplicably ported to XBLA, and that's a damn good thing. But if you're not accustomed to the kind of language and imagery that's an integral part of the show, it can seem a bit overwhelming. (here's a tip: don't die)

That said, it's a definite must-have for fans of ScrewAttack, AVGN, and the classics alike.

reviewText:
First things first, I love the AVGN series (and a lot of other stuff from James Rolfe for that matter), and I was really exited to get this game. However, despite having some really good aspects (music, styling,...), the game sadly resulted in being a precision/timing platformer, in which the smallest mistake will end up in an instant death. Unexpected and really fast moving hazards just end up in annoying trial & error and when there's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of stuff happening on your screen, it'll be more based on luck instead of skills that will help you get through it.
The game also doesn't reset your lives at the start of a new level, so if you have 8/30 lives left, you'll find yourself killing you over and over untill it's game over and the game givces you back 30 lives. Note that the easy setting has unlimited lives.

If you are a big fan of the series and you don't get frustrated fast, you might want to give this game a shot, as for all the others, there's just to much trial & error going on to be enjoyable (as it is not really a challange, but more of  course memorization).

reviewText: While the retro inspired platformers of the past few years have beared only a few measly fruits, this one might be worth checking out. While the games jokes fail to get a laugh out of me and the difficulty at times can be a bit cheap, the gameplay is all around good. The game itself is very well made with nice looking visuals and tight controls. This game, while challenging is very forgiving on all difficulties but the hardest, as it gives you unlimited continues. This game is practically unplayable without a controller so make sure you pick one of those up if you plan to play this game. All around the game is above avarage.

reviewText:
I, personally, have been watching AVGN since 2008. This game marks a huge milestone in his career. As nervous as I was to play it, I can say - - - buy it. I got it for 5 bucks, and if you want a retro like NES game mashup, here's the game for you. The difficulty may be intimidating, but if you play it on Easy, you can get through it. The boss was surprisingly hard, but a big throwback in AVGN's videos.

PROS:

+NES like platformer
+tons of references to AVGN videos
+challenging enough to keep attention
+dialogue /character interactions

CONS:

-a bit of repetition

To some, the game being short and sweet may be a con. GAME LENGTH: approx. 2-3 hours.

reviewText:
I love the Nerd. I love his reviews.

Doesn't mean I like his game. This game is designed for the masochists in the crowd. If you LIKE to play the games he maligns on camera, this game is for you.

That being said, I felt like I was playing IWBTG. And that game scarred me. Do you know how many years it was before Bloody Tears did not send me into a rage after playing that game?

It's deliberately frustrating.

But to the masochists, I offer this.

You can't spell frustration without F, U, and N.

reviewText:
AVGN Adventures is a total recommend if, and only if, you like your games bloody hard.  I mean, this game is harder than any game in the Ghost n' Goblins / Ghouls n' Ghosts series!

The Game controls really well for the most part, but is a tad too slippery, making platforming not as tight as it needs to be.  This isn't a deal breaker, but it may be a controller breaker.

Highlights:

- The Visuals are incredible by 16 bit goodness standards!
- The Music is the pinnacle of chiptune greatness!
- The Humor and Vulgarity are top notch, making this game a must have for AVGN fans!

Lowlights:

- deathblocks.
- deathBLOCKS.
- DEATHBLOCKS!

If you don't like hard games, or are used to playing games like God of War, this game probably isn't for you.  But if you like the Dark Souls, or the Devil May Cry's, then pick this one up!  You will curse like a sailor and cry like Garrus!

reviewText: I intially went into this game with low expectations I have been dissapointed with licensed product before (having played a myriad of movie tie-in shovelware titles in my youth.) However I was very impressed with AVGN Adventures, a game that will appeal to both long-time fans of The Nerd and fans of hardcore retro platformers.\n\nThis title was released in 2013, developed by FreakZone Games and published by ScrewAttack. As shown by The Nerd in his episode AVGN Games"
date: games about The Nerd and his angry world have existed long before this game came out. Many of those titles were homebrew titles often created by one person and released on the Internet for free. AVGN Adventures is the first commercial AVGN game and certainly the title with the highest production value. Visually
recommended: the game features rich and colorful pixel art in additional to some smoothly animated effects (The Nerd exploding into several bits and pieces a la Fallout 3 is a highlight.) The soundtrack hearkens back to the video game days of yore
hoursPlayed: featuring an engrossing score that fits right at home with the games overall difficulty as well as sound effects that further  draw you in.\n\nThe gameplay is almost perfect for a game of this genre
voteText: it's hard but not unfair
helpfulPercent: and it's levels are fun and all vastly different from eachother. My only true gripe with the game is the finicky keyboard controls which unfortunately makes jumping and landing with precision challenging. This problem is of course erased when you plug in an Xbox 360 PC controller
votesHelpful: however it does not erase the games overall difficulty. This game is not recommended for anyone who's not familiar with NES titles like Mega Man
votesTotal: Ninja Gaiden
votesFunny: and Castlevania as the difficulty of this game mimicks that of those classic titles. Also
commentsCount: the game doesn't have much replay value after you complete it for the first time which is acceptable for a $10 game but it would have been a nice feature to unlock additional levels or harder difficulty levels after you complete the game.\n\nIt's definitely worth your money if you like hard-as-nails
