reviewText:
If you're looking for a game with an insane difficulty and a great soundtrack, you found it. For me so far, the game is very good (although I suck miserably at it...) and if you're a fan of The Nerd you're gonna find that the game is incredibly loyal to the series and it's very obvious that the developers put a lot of time into mashing in tributes to things said or done on the show.

However, the game IS extremely hard, so take that into consideration before you buy it. I would not recommend paying more than ten bucks unless you're a really dedicated gamer. Also, I'm personally a huge fan of AVGN - But the jokes can be a little too much sometimes even for me - I'm mostly referring to the cursing on the death-screen, which isn't that funny in the show and just feels kinda forced in the game.

Even if you're not a fan of The Nerd, or if you haven't watched AVGN, the game is a great homage to retro games and definitely worth playing.

reviewText: Wow, just wow. I went into this game with pretty high expectation but I was still blown away. This game is solid, it's hard as hell, but incredibly well made. reviewText: It's good, old-fashioned side-scrolling action at its best. The controls are smooth as butter, the humor is spot-on to the AVGN's style, and the level design is excellent. Each stage feels just difficult enough to keep you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, but not enough that you just up and rage-quit... for the most part. Any avid fan of AVGN will recognize all of the things that makes the web show great, but where it truly shines are the cameos. Many different cameos show up in hidden rooms, including AVGN's friends and companions, as well as ScrewAttack celebrities and various other web personalities. Even if you don't recognize them all, it's still fun to find them. It's gut-wrenchingly difficult, but investing enough time in this game is well worth it. There's a great charm to be had in playing this game.

reviewText:
TL;DR
This retro style platformer is very challenging, but offers great audio and visual treats for the player. Tons of replay value, but not for younger gamers.

Story - 4/10
Gameplay - 8/10
Difficulty - 10/10
Visual - 9/10
Audio - 9/10
Replay Value - 10/10
Family Friendly - 0/10

Introduction
If you dont know anything about the Angry Video Game Nerd, AVGN is a game review  web series where James Rolfe, the creator and star of the series, portrays an angry nerd who Takes you back to the past" and plays terrible games from the NES
recommended: and Atari ages of gaming. The reviews mainly point out flaws and mishaps with the selected games
hoursPlayed:
and does so with the use of heavy profanity and poop jokes...A LOT of profanity.
The first line of the AVGN Theme song is
"He's gonna take you back to the past
To play the sh*tty games that suck *ss"
The Nerd has reviewed  games
voteText: consoles
helpfulPercent:
and even video game accessories throughout 100+ episodes.

Story - 4/10
The intro cut scene tells the simple story this game has. The Nerd and his friends were playing a terrible game one night
votesHelpful: and they were zapped into the game! The Nerd escapes to his basement
votesTotal: but he is quickly seized by a robot arm that comes out of the TV and pulls him in by his ball sack. You play as the Nerd and his friends trying to escape from Gameland.\nA pretty generic story. You are placed in a weird world
votesFunny: and you must escape. The reason that I gave the story a 4 and not lower
commentsCount: is because I can see this ridiculous thing happening in an episode of AVGN. Some of the more thematic episodes of the series involve the Nerd being chased by Jason Vorhees
column16: fighting ROB the Robot
column17:
and even taking a dump on Bugs Bunny's face! Getting sucked into a video game sounds nothing out of the ordinary for the Nerd.

Gameplay - 8/10
This game is a platformer
column18: but it offers some variety of gameplay. This game mainly consists of the player trying to get to the end of the level
column19: but the difficulty is insane.\nIn the "normal" setting
column20: you get three beers
column21: which act as your health. along with 10 lives. The easiest setting gives you six beers with unlimited lives. Most enemies take off one beer
column22: but there are insta-death blocks and lasers as well
column23: in addition to the standard "fall of the screen" death.\nThere are eight different levels of Gameland to play in
column24: each with a different theme based on an existing genre
column29: and even a level based on the Atari porn games titled "Beat it and Eat it".\nEach level has different enemies and design
column30: but they all have insta-death blocks
column32: and these annoying circular-flying enemies that are re-skins for each level. (In one level they are ghosts
column34: they are balls of electricity etc..)\n\nThe default Nerd is only armed with an NES baster gun as a weapon
column36: the Nerd can get help from his friends who offer some special abilities. The other characters are also from the AVGN web series. While the game is able to be completed with just the Nerd
column37: his friends come in handy at times.\nGuitar Guy can run faster and shoot through walls using his guitar.\nMother F*cker Mike can jump higher and longer
column39: but his attack is a melee lightsaber. He cannot move while attacking. He can also see through walls
column42: and save points.\nThe B*llsh*t Man can throw turds at enemies
column43: but only at a short distance. However
column44: he can double jump by farting
column45: which allows access to previously unreachable areas.\n\nThere are also special attacks that can be picked up throughout the game
column47: who “glitches out” every enemy on screen
column48: making them easier to kill. The Super-Mecha-Death-Christ powerup kills all enemies on screen. There is also a joke “rock” powerup. You can throw them at enemies
column49: but the rocks arc over everything
column51:
but is used in various real games the Nerd has reviewed.

Difficulty – 10/10
I have only beaten this game on the easy mode. With six beers and unlimited lives
column52: it was still difficult. Literally everything in this game is trying to kill you. There are walking enemies
column59:
and more. I cannot fathom how anybody can beat this game above the normal setting.

Visual - 9/10
The graphics in this game are superb. It really captures the style of the old-school NES. The animations are spot-on
column60:
and the color schemes of the levels are outstanding. There isnt much I can say about it without showing you the game itself.

Audio – 9/10
Much like the visuals
column61: I can't really give the audio justice without you actually hearing it. The music in this game is phenomenal. Each track is memorable and fits the mood of the game that you're in. The title screen is a chip tune version of the AVGN theme
column62: the level select screen gets enhanced after unlocking the final level
column63:
each level track is amazing for a minute long loop. I don't know what else to say except for you to listen for yourself!

Replay Value – 10/10
There is tons of replay value in this game. After discovering the other three characters
column64: you can go back and find all of the hidden Sh*tpickles (another character from AVGN). They don't do anything besides you get an achievement for finding them all. After beating the game on easy
column65: you can refine your skills in Normal
column67: and the other advanced settings where the beers and lives become fewer
column68:
and the enemies become harder to kill.

Family Friendly – 0/10
As you have probably noticed from the names of the characters
column69: this game is not for children. The nerd curses (all through text boxes) during different levels
column71: and sections of the game. Each time you die
column72: the death screen shows a randomly generated phrase “I'd rather X X from a X's X than play this X game!” one of the less profane ones ive gotten was “I'd rather chew urine from a potato's butt crack then play this crummy game!”The Nerd flips you the bird if you leave him idling for too long
column73: and when you start up the game
column74: the first thing you see is “RATED 'F' FOR F*CKBALLS”\nThe worst part
column75: is that there is no way to filter out these obscene things. I'm afraid to play this game in around my family because of all the profanity in this game. Sure
column76: the AVGN series is filled with it
column77: so I guess it fits to have it in the game
column78: but I was shocked when I first played it. There was no warning or disclaimer telling me of this on the Steam store page. If you are heavily offended by profanity
column79: do not pick up this game.\n\nSo there you have it! My review of Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures. Overall
column80: it's a good game. It can be difficult most of the time
column81: but what it lacks in easiness
column82: it makes up for in audio and art style. I say that it's listed on Steam at a fair price."

reviewText: This game is terrible! It is full of cheap kills and vulgar language via this Nerd" character who is nothing more than a cheap megaman knockoff who proceeds to whine about every single thing this stupid game has to offer. There are not very many levels and all of them are crafted with the level design equivalent of something an 11 year old boy drew on a piece of paper when he was supposed to be paying attention to math class. Tons of one-hit kill blocks muck up what could have at least been a mediocre yet fun little romp through the somewhat clever parody levels of other much better games. But that's it there are only 6 or 7 levels! That's HALF of one megaman game. Also this nerd is not your only character you play as. He has friends - go figure - a nerd with friends! Doesn't seem very nerdy if you A) have friends and B) have a cool gun that you fire at everything. That's what cool people have! In fact the only thing nerdy about this stereotype is that hes got glasses and whines!\n\nThe other characters all suck and do not help you out in any way and the collectible "♥♥♥♥ pickles" add nothing to the game. reviewText: It's good, old-fashioned side-scrolling action at its best. The controls are smooth as butter, the humor is spot-on to the AVGN's style, and the level design is excellent. Each stage feels just difficult enough to keep you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, but not enough that you just up and rage-quit... for the most part. Any avid fan of AVGN will recognize all of the things that makes the web show great, but where it truly shines are the cameos. Many different cameos show up in hidden rooms, including AVGN's friends and companions, as well as ScrewAttack celebrities and various other web personalities. Even if you don't recognize them all, it's still fun to find them. It's gut-wrenchingly difficult, but investing enough time in this game is well worth it. There's a great charm to be had in playing this game.
